question: What topics are covered in the initial orientation courses?
context:
German courses for initial orientation
German courses for initial orientation
The German courses for initial language orientation (also known as initial orientation courses) teach both basic German language skills and information about life in Germany.
They are a practical starting aid in the new living environment and make everyday life easier.
A course comprises 300 teaching units of 45 minutes each and covers topics such as "Health/medical care", "Work", "Kindergarten/school", "Housing", "Local orientation/transport/mobility".
The focus is on oral communication: participants should learn as quickly as possible to find their way around in everyday life.
Across all modules, initial orientation courses are also about teaching values.
Initial orientation courses are primarily intended for asylum seekers with unclear prospects of remaining in Germany.
However, if there are free places, recognized asylum seekers, tolerated persons and asylum seekers with good prospects of staying may also take part.
Anyone who is still required to attend school (6 to 15 years) or vocational school (16 to 21 years) does not attend the initial orientation course, but attends school or a school-based measure.
If you gain access to an "" integration course during your participation in the initial orientation course, you can switch to this course.
The people on the courses have very different backgrounds.
Illiterate people as well as academics can attend the courses.
Initial orientation courses are free of charge.
The course language is German - interpreters are not present during the course.
Contact a "" migration advice center or your local "" refugee and integration advice center in your accommodation.
They will help you to find a suitable course.
Learn more

question: When does your freedom end?
context:
Personal freedom
Personal freedom
All adults are entitled to make their own decisions about themselves and their own lives.
Whether man or woman, young or old, with or without a disability, regardless of skin color or religious affiliation.
All people are allowed to do what they want as long as they abide by the law and do not restrict the freedom of others.
This means, for example:
Everyone can decide what they want to wear.
Women can decide whether they want to wear pants, dresses, long or short skirts, tight or loose clothing or a headscarf.
Men can decide whether to wear a suit and tie, a T-shirt and jeans, a turban, a hat or a beard.
Everyone is allowed to eat what they want and what they like.
The decision whether to eat meat (including pork or beef) is made by people alone.
The state has no generally valid or religiously based dietary regulations.
The consumption of alcohol is permitted for adults.
The consumption of alcohol by children and young people is prohibited.
Every woman and every man can decide for themselves whether and who they want to marry.
Every woman and every man is entitled to divorce.
Unmarried couples are allowed to live together and have children.
Members of different religions and faiths are allowed to marry and have children.
Contraception is permitted for both sexes.
A person's decision to use contraception must be respected.
Same-sex partnerships are accepted.
Same-sex couples can marry.
The rights of a civil partnership are similar to those of a marriage between a man and a woman.
Everyone decides for themselves how and where they want to live.
For persons in the asylum procedure, this right may be restricted until an asylum application is recognized.
Sexual acts between adults may only take place with mutual consent.
Any sexual activity with children is prohibited.
Private property is permitted for every man and every woman in Germany.
It is permitted to own a house or a plot of land.
Many companies are privately owned.
Women and men have equal rights when it comes to inheritance.
Important:
One's own freedom ends where it infringes the freedom or human dignity of others or violates the law.

question: On what legal basis are refugees recognized?
context:
Forms of protection in the asylum procedure
Forms of protection in the asylum procedure
If you apply for asylum, you are applying for protection in Germany and will not be deported.
The law provides for various forms of protection.
They correspond to different forms of persecution in the country of origin.
In an asylum procedure, it is checked which form of protection can be granted to you based on your individual situation.
Below you will find a brief overview of the various forms of protection.
You will find more detailed information in German, English, Turkish, Russian, French and Arabic under the links provided.
Eligibility for asylum
According to Art.
16 A of the Basic Law (Grundgesetz - GG) of the Federal Republic of Germany grants asylum to politically persecuted persons.
This protection status can be granted to persons who, due to
their ethnicity
their nationality
their political convictions
their basic religious decisions or
their membership of a particular social group (for example, on the basis of sexual orientation)
will be exposed to state persecution and serious human rights violations in their country of origin if they were to return.
Learn more
Refugee protection
According to the Geneva Refugee Convention, people are considered refugees if they are affected by state or non-state persecution for one of the following reasons and are outside their country of origin:
Ethnicity
Religion
Nationality
political conviction
Belonging to a certain social group (for example due to sexual orientation)
Legal basis: § 3 para.
Asylum Act (AsylG)
Learn more
Subsidiary protection
People who are at risk of serious harm in their country of origin and who cannot claim protection in their country of origin are eligible for subsidiary protection.
The threat can come from both governmental and non-governmental sources.
These include:
Death penalty
Torture
inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment
serious individual threat to the life or integrity of a civilian as a result of indiscriminate violence in an international or internal armed conflict
Legal basis: § 4 para.
1A sylG
Learn more
National ban on deportation
A person seeking protection may not be deported if
repatriation constitutes a violation of the European Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (ECHR) or
there is a considerable concrete danger to life, limb or freedom in the country of destination.
Legal basis: § 60 para.
5 AufenthG, § 60 para.
7 Residence Act

question: How many votes does each voter have in the migration council election?
context:
How you can choose
How you can choose
In this election, you decide who gets a place on the Migration Advisory Council.
You have 40 votes.
The nominations (= lists) with the candidates for the migration council election are finalized at the end of January.
Ballot paper
On the ballot paper, all election proposals are sorted by initial letters from A to Z.
Each list has a number, a password and numbered candidates.
Each person's name, nationality and profession are listed.
Here you will find
all election proposals (lists) and one
Sample ballot.
You can also use a
Online trial ballot, test how the distribution of votes works.
Distribute votes
You have 40 votes.
If you distribute more votes, the ballot paper is invalid.
Here are four examples of how you can distribute the votes:
(1) Distribute votes freely
You can distribute your votes freely to the candidates on the entire ballot paper.
You tick all the people you want to vote for, regardless of which list they are on.
This is known as variegation.
You can also give special support to individuals and give them not just one vote, but two, but a maximum of three votes.
You can check the name multiple times.
Or you can write the number of votes (1, 2 or 3) in the box next to the name.
This is known as accumulation.
Please make sure that no one receives more than three votes from you.
(2) Select list
You can also select a complete list.
You only need to check the list once at the top of the password.
Your votes will then go to the candidates on this list in turn until all 40 votes have been distributed.
People who are listed three times get three votes.
People who are listed there twice receive two votes.
(3) Select list - with changes
If you select an entire list, you can still change something according to your wishes.
For example, you can delete one or more names from the list.
These people then do not get a vote.
You can also give special support to people on the list by giving them two or three votes.
(4) Select list and distribute additional votes freely
A mixed form is also possible: you can vote for a list (with or without changes) and also distribute votes freely.
This means that you can also tick people on other lists on the ballot paper and give them up to three votes.
The counting then proceeds as follows: On your ballot paper, all the votes you have given to individual persons are added up first.
What then of your
40 votes left will go to the list you ticked.
This means that all remaining votes go in turn to the persons on this list.
So no voice is lost.
All examples can also be found in the
Information sheet "How to vote".
Use the
Online sample order form to try out.
Test your vote.

question: What requirements must be met for the residence permit in Germany to be terminated?
context:
Taxes and social security contributions
Taxes and social security contributions
Every employee pays part of their salary in taxes and social security contributions.
If you are self-employed, you must also pay taxes.
Income tax
Income tax contributes to the financing of federal, state and local government expenditure.
Taxpayers' money is used to build roads and schools, for example, or to finance social benefits.
If you are employed, you will receive the net amount of your salary from your employer, i.e. your taxes have already been deducted.
If you are self-employed, you are responsible for paying tax on your income.
Tax identification number
All employees receive a "tax identification number" at the start of their employment.
This tax ID is an 11-digit number and is used for income tax purposes.
It is valid for a lifetime.
Children born in Germany receive a letter with their personal tax ID within three months of birth, which is also required, for example, to apply for child benefit.
If you work in Germany, you will need the number again and again, for example for your employer.
If you do not know the number, you can ask for it in person at the registration office or in writing at the Federal Tax Office.
Tax return
In your annual tax return, you can claim various expenses from the tax office as tax-reducing.
This may result in either repayments in your favor or additional payments to the tax office.
Many people are required to submit a tax return, so it is best to ask the tax office whether this applies to you.
If you need help with your tax return, it is best to contact your local income tax association.
If you have further questions, the tax office can also help you.
Social security contributions
Social security contributions are the social security contributions that employees have to pay from their gross monthly salary in addition to taxes - this is mandatory by law and is automatically calculated by the employer.
Part of the social insurance is also paid by the employer.
Social security contributions finance the German social system.
If people cannot find work or are no longer able to work, the most basic living expenses can be secured in this way.
Ultimately, social security contributions serve the personal security of each and every individual - for example, if you become unemployed and have previously paid into unemployment insurance for a certain period of time, you are entitled to unemployment benefit I. Your monthly contribution to pension insurance also entitles you to a state pension in old age.
Social security contributions are made up of contributions for:
Pension insurance
Unemployment insurance
Health insurance
Long-term care insurance
The amount depends on the individual income.
The contributions are automatically deducted from your gross salary.
Exceptions for foreign employees apply, for example, if they have been posted to Germany by a foreign company, are employed or self-employed in several countries or are affected by other exemptions.
One of the requirements for a permanent residence permit is that you have paid pension insurance contributions for at least 60 months.
This also applies to self-employed persons.
There are also exceptions to this rule.
Social security number
German Pension Insurance will automatically send you your social security number by post when you take up your first job in Germany.
If you lose your number, you can ask to be notified again:

School vacations
Summer vacation
The summer vacation period varies from state to state.
In Bavaria, they usually cover the whole of August and the first two weeks of September.
The duration of the vacation is six weeks.
Fall vacation
The fall vacations are around the All Saints' Day holiday (November 1) and usually last one week.
Christmas vacation
The two-week Christmas vacation usually includes Christmas Eve (24.12.) and the Three Kings holiday (6.1.).
Spring break
The one-week spring break begins on Shrove Monday.
Easter vacation
The Easter weekend is in the middle of the two-week Easter vacation.
Whitsun vacation
The Christian festival of Pentecost lies at the beginning of the two-week Pentecost vacation.

question: What happens if you exceed the visa-free period?
context:

Entry / stay without a visa
Citizens of the following countries may enter the country without a visa
Schengen area: Australia, New Zealand, the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, Israel, Japan, Canada, the Republic of Korea, the United States of America.
These are the so-called privileged states.
They may stay in Schengen territory for up to 90 days within a 180-day period (90/180 rule).
If you are planning multiple entries or longer stays, you must take this into account.
Set the departure date so that the total of 90 days is not exceeded.
The calculation is often complicated and visitors do not know whether they have already spent their 90 days in the Schengen area or not.
It is therefore important to keep track of the days.
This
Online calculators can help.
List of countries that require a visa for entry (visa requirement)
Please note: At the end of the maximum period of stay, you must not only leave Germany, but the entire Schengen area.
If you want to stay or work here for longer than three months, you must apply for a residence permit at the "" Foreigners' Registration Office.
If it is not possible to leave the country within the deadline, the Foreigners' Registration Office must be contacted before the deadline expires.
Reasons can be
Force majeure (An unforeseeable event caused by external circumstances that could not have been prevented.
This can be a natural event such as an earthquake, but also war or a pandemic)
Humanitarian, professional or serious personal reasons
be taken into account.
If you exceed the visa-free stay without having applied for a residence permit, your stay is not permitted (violation of the law).
The foreigners authority can terminate the stay.
Re-entry would only be possible again if there is no re-entry ban.
There may also be criminal proceedings in court.

question: What is not allowed in Germany?
context:
Religious freedom
Religious freedom
Religion and faith are private matters in Germany.
The state does not dictate to anyone whether and in which God he or she should believe.
State and religion are separate.
This means, for example:
All people are free to practise and choose their religion and beliefs.
All people have the freedom to be non-religious and to say so.
Anyone who does not believe in God is allowed to say so publicly.
Members of different religions and faiths are allowed to marry each other.
Marriage only counts as a legally valid marriage if it is concluded before the registry office.
Marriages entered into exclusively within the framework of a religion are not legally binding in Germany.
This is not permitted in Germany, for example:
Putting religious rules or traditions above applicable laws, for example being married to several women at the same time or slaughtering an animal without special permission.
Boys may only be circumcised if this does not endanger their welfare.
Many people in Germany today are committed to dialog between religions.
The aim is the peaceful coexistence of religious people, people of faith and people of no religion.
The state is committed to ideological neutrality.
As long as the practice of a religion does not endanger democracy or the separation of state and religion, it is protected.

Net cold rent = basic rent without operating costs
plus

Heating and hot water costs are taken into account separately.

If you are threatened with homelessness, we will work with you to find a
Social community center a solution.
Relocation
If you want to move, your case worker must check whether the move is necessary and the costs of the new home are reasonable before concluding the tenancy agreement.
The following evidence and documents are required for verification:
Written justification of the reason for the move (if necessary, appropriate evidence proving an important reason)
Unsigned tenancy agreement or an offer of accommodation showing all costs associated with renting the accommodation (e.g. basic rent, ancillary costs and heating costs, deposit).
An important reason exists, for example, if:
the move eliminates imminent or existing homelessness;
the move ends or avoids the need for assistance;
the move is necessary in order to take up or continue gainful employment subject to social insurance contributions at a greater distance (commute to work, depending on working hours, more than 2-2.5 hours total travel time).

Holders of a valid Schengen visa (text on the visa label: "valid for Schengen states" in the language of the issuing state) may stay in the entire Schengen area for a period of 180 days up to 90 days.
Learn more
Please note that you must leave the country within the period of validity of your visa.
This requires leaving the Schengen area.
A Schengen visa that has not been issued by the embassy for three months can be extended in Germany.
However, the requirements for this must still be met.
It is not possible to change the purpose of the visa.
The application must be justified;
in particular can
force majeure,
Humanitarian, professional or serious personal reasons
be taken into account.
If you do not have your visa extended by the "" Foreigners' Registration Office and only leave the country after your visa has expired, you are breaking the law.
The Foreigners' Registration Office will then check whether your stay must be terminated.
Re-entry would only be possible if there is no re-entry ban.
There may also be criminal proceedings in court.

question: What information is mandatory in the payslip or pay slip?
context:

Payroll accounting
If you are employed, you will receive a payslip or payslip after the first month.
Some employers will continue to issue you with a monthly statement, others only if something is different in the month in question (e.g. Christmas bonus, increase in insurance contributions, etc.).
Mandatory information in the pay slip or payslip:
Name and address of the employer
Name, address, date of birth of the employee
Insurance number of the employer
Date of start of employment
Tax class and tax identification number
Billing period
Gross salary (salary without deductions - gross tax amount and gross social security amount)
Type and amount of supplements or allowances
Type and amount of deductions
Net amount (after all deductions)
The net amount is usually the amount paid out.
Exception: In the case of advances, loans from the company or salary garnishments (if you have debts), further amounts are deducted from the net amount.

question: When is private liability insurance required by law?
context:
Insurances
Liability insurance
If you cause damage to a person in Germany, the law states that you must pay for the damage, even if you did not cause the damage intentionally.
This applies to personal injury, property damage and financial losses in the private sector.
For example, if you cause a traffic accident or if your child breaks a window pane with a ball.
You can take out personal liability insurance to pay for such damage for you and your family.
It is not compulsory to have this insurance, but it is highly recommended, as otherwise you may be faced with very high costs in the event of a claim.
The migration advice centers can help you find a good offer for private liability insurance.
Learn more

The children eat lunch together.

question: What does Article 3 of the Basic Law say?
context:
Equal rights for women and men
Equal rights for women and men
Women and men have the same rights in Germany.
This is enshrined in Article 3 of the Basic Law.
Women can learn German, go to the doctor, learn a profession and look for a job.
You do not need permission from your husband or other family members.
Women can marry whoever they want and also separate or divorce if the relationship is not working or if the partner is violent.
You can be in a relationship with a man or a woman or live alone.
When couples separate, the children can live with the mother, with the father or partly with the mother and partly with the father.
If the parents cannot agree on where the children should live, the court decides what is best for the children.
Despite equal rights, women are sometimes disadvantaged at work, in everyday life or in the family.
There are various counseling centers for women.
There you can find out about your rights and get help so that you can lead an independent and equal life.
You can find more information on the topic of equal rights here:
Handbook "Women in Munich", published by the Equal Opportunities Office for Women of the City of Munich;
comprehensive publication with many useful addresses and offers.
Federal Ministry for Family Affairs, Senior Citizens, Women and Youth

The site also contains other short films on the most important aspects of the German legal system.

question: What is meant by irregular employment?
context:
Irregular and illegal employment
Irregular and illegal employment
Work that is paid but not registered with the tax office and health insurance fund and for which no taxes and social security contributions are therefore paid is illegal and is referred to as "irregular employment" in Germany.
Fines and prison sentences are threatened!
If someone receives social benefits or unemployment benefit but still works and conceals this from the social welfare office, employment agency or job center, this is called illegal employment: You receive state benefits even though you are in paid employment.
This is prohibited and against the law.
A colloquial term for this is "moonlighting".
Always inform the office from which you receive benefits if you wish to take up work;
It is permitted to earn money while receiving benefits (benefits will then be recalculated), but you are obliged to declare any earnings and income immediately.
Taking up employment despite a work ban is also considered illegal employment.
Depending on the country of origin and reason for residence, illegal employment can lead to an indefinite ban on working!

question: Where are asylum seekers sent back to if Germany is not responsible?
context:
3. the Dublin procedure
Dublin procedure
The Dublin procedure covers the territory of the 28 EU member states as well as Norway, Iceland, Liechtenstein and Switzerland.
It determines which state is responsible for carrying out your asylum procedure.
As a rule, it is the country in which you were first registered.
An electronic data comparison is carried out for this purpose.
If it has been determined that Germany is not responsible for carrying out your asylum procedure, you will be sent back to the country responsible for you.
If you do not agree with this decision, you should seek professional legal advice on whether it makes sense to file a complaint with the administrative court.

question: What is a Sprengelschule?
context:
Compulsory schooling and school districts
Compulsory schooling and school districts
Compulsory schooling
School attendance is compulsory in Germany: all children between the ages of 6 and 15 have to go to school.
Thereafter, the following applies in Bavaria until the age of 21
Vocational school attendance is compulsory from the age of 18 if attendance at a general school is not continued.
Compulsory vocational schooling does not apply if the school was completed with the Abitur or Fachabitur.
Parents ensure that their children attend school regularly.
Attending public (state and municipal) schools costs nothing.
If a child is ill, parents must call the school before 08:00 in the morning.
School district
If the child attends a public primary or secondary school, it must go to the school that is responsible for its place of residence - a Sprengelschule.
"Sprengel" means "school district".

School attendance is compulsory in Germany: all children between the ages of 6 and 15 have to go to school.
Thereafter, the following applies in Bavaria until the age of 21
Vocational school attendance is compulsory from the age of 18 if attendance at a general school is not continued.
Compulsory vocational schooling does not apply if the school was completed with the Abitur or Fachabitur.
Parents ensure that their children attend school regularly.
Attending public (state and municipal) schools costs nothing.
If a child is ill, parents must call the school before 08:00 in the morning.
School district
If the child attends a public primary or secondary school, it must go to the school that is responsible for its place of residence - a Sprengelschule.
"Sprengel" means "school district".

question: How do I fill in Asylum Protection Forms correctly?
context:
Forms of protection in the asylum procedure
Forms of protection in the asylum procedure
Many people are persecuted in their home country.
People can receive protection in Germany.
You have to apply for asylum.
When you apply for asylum, you start an asylum procedure.
It decides whether you are allowed to stay in Germany.
There are various forms of protection under German law.
Because there are different forms of persecution.
Your situation will be looked at closely during the asylum procedure.
You will then be granted a form of protection.
Here you will find an overview of the forms of protection.
Under the links you will find information in German, English, Turkish, Russian, French and Arabic.
Eligibility for asylum
Politically persecuted people are granted asylum in Germany.
This is stated in the Basic Law (Art.
16 A).
You will receive protection status if you are persecuted by the state in your home country because of
Your ethnicity
Your nationality
Your political convictions
Your religion or
Your membership of a particular social group (for example, due to sexual orientation).
Some people also fear punishment if they return to their home country.
This form of protection also applies in this case.
Learn more
Refugee protection
The Geneva Refugee Convention has defined who is considered a refugee.
The definition says: A refugee is outside the country of origin.
He is prosecuted by the state or non-state authorities for one of the following:
Ethnicity
Religion
Nationality
political conviction
Belonging to a certain social group (for example due to sexual orientation)
Legal basis: § 3 para.
Asylum Act (AsylG)
Learn more
Subsidiary protection
People who are at risk of serious harm in their country of origin are eligible for subsidiary protection.
Or who cannot claim the protection of their country of origin.
The threat can come from a governmental or non-governmental source.
These include:
Death penalty
Torture
inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment
serious individual threat to the life or integrity of a civilian as a result of indiscriminate violence in an international or internal armed conflict
Legal basis: § 4 para.
1AsylG
Learn more
National ban on deportation
A person seeking protection may not be deported if
repatriation constitutes a violation of the European Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (ECHR) or
there is a considerable concrete danger to life, limb or freedom in the country of destination.
Legal basis: § 60 para.
5 AufenthG, § 60 para.
7 Residence Act

question: How does the "settlement permit" differ from the "residence permit"?
context:

What residence permits are available for permanent residence?
Settlement permit according to § 9 Residence Act
With a settlement permit, you can live and work in Germany.
Without time and location restrictions.
Prerequisites are for example:
Legal residence in Germany for at least 5 years (previous periods of study and training are credited at 50%)
valid residence permit that was not issued for a temporary purpose (studies) or for humanitarian reasons
Proof of secure livelihood
Proof of secured living space
Proof of sufficient pension provision (at least 60 months of compulsory or voluntary contributions to statutory pension insurance in Germany)
sufficient German language skills and basic knowledge of the legal and social system and living conditions in Germany - usually demonstrated by
successful participation in an integration course
or
through certificates and proof of study relating to vocational training completed in Germany
or
other language certificates
In individual cases, you may need additional documents.
You can find more information on the requirements here.
Permanent residence - EU
Permanent residence - EU is an unlimited residence permit.
It offers the same rights as the settlement permit.
With the permit you can live and work in Germany.
Without time and location restrictions.
You can also live, work or study in other EU countries.
Exceptions are Ireland and Denmark.
Special regulations apply for individual countries.
You can find information on the requirements here.
Which residence permit is right for you?
That depends on your individual circumstances.
The Office for Immigration and Integration will be happy to advise you.

People with professional experience are allowed to come to Germany.

Persons without a professional qualification recognized abroad must have their professional qualification recognized in Germany.
3) Potential
People without a concrete job offer can also work in Germany.
The opportunity card was introduced for them.
It is based on a points system.
These criteria are taken into account:
Qualification
German and English language skills
Professional experience
Reference to Germany
Age
Potential of spouses and partners

Are you an asylum seeker?
And you were born before 29.
Then you can apply for a residence permit as a skilled worker.
You don't have to leave the country for this.
And you don't have to go through a visa procedure.
You have to withdraw your application for asylum.

question: When should you be careful when paying online?
context:
Online shopping
More and more people are shopping online.
There are a few things to bear in mind.
Remember that:
Online shopping does not only have positive effects.
Packaging material and returns are a burden on the environment.
And even local stores cannot keep up with the competition on the Internet.
That's why many stores are closing.
The local stores are empty.
It is therefore worth considering what you order on the Internet or buy directly on site.
What should I look out for when shopping online?
Reputable online store or fake store?
Want to order something online?
Then you should find out about the online store beforehand.
Because not all platforms are reputable.
So-called fake stores offer cheap goods that you do not receive after payment or that you receive in poor condition.
How can I recognize a dubious online retailer?
Strikingly low price
The goods in the online store are remarkably cheap?
However, this is not always an indication of a fake store.
But you should take a closer look.
Conspicuous Internet address
A well-known website suddenly shows inconsistencies?
The domain extension has been extended (e.g.
B. instead of ".de" it says: ".de.com")?
The Internet address contains the keyword "plants", but it sells shoes?
Then these are signs of a fake store.
No imprint:
Every online store in the EU must have an imprint.
If the legal notice is missing, it is a sign of a dubious online store.
However, the fraudsters know this too.
Therefore, make sure that the imprint includes the following: Address, representative, e-mail address, reference to the commercial register.
If these criteria are met, it is highly likely that you are dealing with a reputable store.
Missing GTC (General Terms and Conditions) and termination conditions
GTCs are pre-formulated contractual terms and conditions.
So these are rules that apply to every purchase from this online store.
If you cannot find any terms and conditions on the site, then you should be careful with this online store.
A reputable online store will provide information about the terms of termination.
You have a right of withdrawal with every purchase.
Insecure payment methods
Normally the rule is: first the goods, then the payment.
However, many stores also offer prepayment.
Prepayment means: You transfer the money before the goods are dispatched.
Many payment methods are offered?
But in the last step you can only select "Prepayment" as the payment method?
Then be careful!
False quality seals
Many fake stores use quality seals to gain the trust of potential customers.
Do you see a quality seal on an online store?
Then click on it.
If the quality seal is not linked to the corresponding website, then it is probably a fake.
Missing or only positive customer reviews
Customer reviews on the online store's website are not always meaningful.
Often only positive reviews are published.
The bad ratings will be deleted.
You can also search for customer reviews on other platforms.
No encrypted connection
Make sure that the online store has an encrypted connection.
Especially if you have to enter your data or bank details.
Insufficient product descriptions
Does the product description match the goods or services offered?
If not, it could be a fake store.
Shortcomings in the offer
You should be informed about delivery times and shipping costs before making a purchase.
Be careful if this is not the case.
Lack of contact options
Avoid online stores that only offer an e-mail address or a chargeable telephone number as a contact option.
You can easily check whether an online store is reputable with the Fake Shop Finder from the consumer advice center: Fake Shop Finder.
Tips for safe online shopping
Be careful when entering your data.
Of course, the online store needs your name and address for delivery.
But sometimes other things are also asked.
Think about whether you really want to specify them.
Choose online stores wisely.
Pay attention to the criteria listed above.
Compare the prices with offers in the store.
Not everything is cheaper on the Internet.
Pay attention to the total price: Is the price shown really the final purchase price (including taxes, customs duties and shipping costs)?

question: What options do I have with dual training?
context:
Vocational school
Germany is well known for its dual education system.
The vocational school is part of the dual training system.
Who attends a vocational school?
Some young people have to attend a vocational school.
These are young people who...
do an apprenticeship and
are between 16 and 21 years old.
They are subject to compulsory vocational training.
Trainees with an Abitur or Fachhochschulreife are not required to attend vocational school.
You are still allowed to attend vocational school.
Duration and aim of the vocational school
Duration: two to three years
Goal: completed vocational training
Graduation: Vocational qualification, intermediate school leaving certificate
What do you learn at vocational school?
The task of the vocational school is to impart theoretical knowledge for the respective occupation.
Practical knowledge is acquired in the training company.
But there are also other subjects.
For example:
German
Social studies
Religious education
Sport (partial)
Foreign languages (partial)
There are also elective subjects (e.g.
B. Data processing, English).
You can take electives on a voluntary basis.
But you don't have to.
How and when do the lessons take place?
Vocational school lasts as long as your training in the company.
The times are regulated differently.
There are:
Part-time lessons on individual days of the week (1-2 days each week)
Part-time teaching as block teaching;
mostly for training occupations with small numbers of trainees (e.g.
B. nine weeks in the company, followed by three weeks of vocational school)
Full-time instruction (only in the basic vocational school year and vocational preparation year;
see below: "Young people without a training place")
How can things continue after that?
You have these options after completing vocational school:
Working in your profession
Attending a technical college or academy
Attending the Berufsoberschule (BOS)
Young people without an apprenticeship
Young people do not always find a training place.
If they have not yet completed compulsory schooling, they are required to attend vocational school.
You have these two options:
1st basic vocational school year (BGJ-s for short)
The basic vocational school year is aimed at young people who have not yet found a training place.
The vocational school also provides practical training in the first year of the apprenticeship.
After successfully completing the course, the apprentice immediately enters the 2nd year of training.
However, there are also training areas in which the BGJ is compulsory.
These include:
Occupations with wood (e.g.
B. Carpenter)
Professions in agriculture
Professions in housekeeping
2. vocational preparation year (BVJ for short)
The BVJ prepares young people for an apprenticeship or vocational activity within one year.
Compulsory vocational school attendance is deemed to have been fulfilled upon successful completion of the BVJ.
If vocational training is subsequently undertaken, the person is again deemed to be required to attend vocational school.
More information is available from the Neusäß State Vocational School Center:
State Vocational School Center Neusäß (BSZ)

sekretariat@bszneusaess.de

question: How can people without certificates prove their professional experience and skills?
context:
Recognition of foreign professional qualifications
In Germany, certificates play an important role for school, university or work.
They are proof of what you have already learned and achieved.
Certificates of school-leaving qualifications or professional qualifications are the decisive prerequisite for getting a job, a training place or a place at university.
If you have already obtained qualifications at school, in an apprenticeship or at university abroad, it often makes sense for the certificates to be recognized in Germany.
This means that they will check what you are qualified to do in Germany based on your certificates.
It may be that you no longer have your certificates.
In this case, you can try to prove your professional experience and skills through tests.
IQ recognition and qualification advice
Have you completed a vocational qualification abroad?
Have you already gained professional experience abroad?
Then the Recognition and Qualification Advisory Service is the right place for you to go.
The advice center will look at your documents.
She then compares your qualification with the German qualification.
For example, duration or content is compared.
Relevant professional experience is also taken into account.
At the end you will receive an assessment of whether you can get recognition or not.
Sometimes there are too big differences between foreign and German qualifications.
Because there are many factors to consider when recognizing professional qualifications, it is best to seek advice:
Door to door - Recognition and qualification advice
anerkennungsberatung@tuerantuer.de
www.migranet.org/angebote/ratsuchende/anerkennungsberatung
Telephone consultation hours: Monday and Thursday from 10 a.m. to 12 noon, Tuesday from 2 p.m. to 4 p.m.
Recognition grant
The recognition of foreign qualifications costs money.
The costs vary depending on the profession.
Some people can apply for a recognition grant.
This affects people who
live permanently in Germany,
have a low income and
are working below their professional qualification.
Get advice directly by e-mail or phone:
Research Institute for Vocational Education and Training (f-bb) gGmbH
anerkennungszuschuss@f-bb.de

question: Where can I find a midwife?
context:
Important information on pregnancy and birth
Pregnant women are under special protection in Germany.
You are entitled to advice and medical care.
Guide to maternal health
The "Guide to Maternal Health" provides answers to many specific questions.
It is available in seven languages:
English
Kurdish
Russian
Turkish
Arabic
Serbo-Croatian
Pregnant - and now?
If you are pregnant, you must first go to the gynecologist.
to the gynecologist (gynecologist or
gynecologist).
Have the check-ups carried out there.
You will then receive a maternity pass.
The maternity record is a document containing important information about your pregnancy, your health and that of your child.
Always take your maternity pass with you in case of emergencies.
During pregnancy and in the postnatal period, pregnant women can be accompanied by a midwife.
Would you like support from a midwife?
Then it's best to search early!
Each midwife can only look after a few pregnant women.
They are therefore booked up early.
You can find a midwife, for example, via the midwife list of the pregnancy advice center at the Augsburg District Office.
For medical questions about family planning, pregnancy and birth
On the "Zanzu" portal you will find information in 13 languages on topics such as family planning and pregnancy.
There is also a dictionary of medical terms.
The MiMi health project (with migrants for migrants) provides information on the individual stages of pregnancy in the "Guide to maternal health".
The guide (search term: maternal health) is available at
Arabic
German
English

Russian

Turkish
Maternity protection for working pregnant women
Working pregnant women enjoy special protection - known as maternity protection.
Maternity protection begins six weeks before the birth and ends eight weeks afterwards.
This protection is regulated by law in Germany.
Pregnant women are generally not allowed to work during this time.
Your workplace remains intact.
You can return to work at the end of your maternity leave.
In addition, pregnant women may not work more than 8.5 hours per day.
They are also not allowed to do any heavy physical work.
You can find out more about this from your employer, from one of the advice centers listed below or here.
Financial support
If you have little or no income, you can apply for unemployment benefit II or social assistance.
After the twelfth week of pregnancy, the Jobcenter or social welfare office will pay expectant mothers an additional requirement.
And also the initial equipment for pregnancy and baby.
Delivery and aftercare
Your gynecologist will refer you to a maternity clinic.
Ask there for a midwife for aftercare.
If the clinic does not provide a midwife, contact "Frühe Hilfen/ KoKi".
You will receive a birth certificate from the clinic.
You need a birth certificate from the registry office to apply for a birth certificate for your child.
You also need the birth certificate if you are applying for parental allowance.
Notification to the registry office
Newborn children must be registered with the registry office.
The maternity clinic is responsible for registering the birth with the registry office.
For the birth certificate you need:
Your ID card
the birth certificate from the clinic
Your marriage certificate (if available)
What to do in the event of an unwanted pregnancy?
Pregnancy is not always desirable.
There are opportunities for support in the district.

women who wish to terminate their pregnancy ("pregnancy conflict counseling") or
nobody should know about the birth ("confidential birth").

question: What documents are required for the asylum appeal procedure?
context:
Legal action
Legal action
You do not agree with the negative decision on your asylum application by the BAMF?
Then you can sue.
You are the "plaintiff" or the "claimant".
The BAMF is the "defendant".
In the event of an appeal, the Munich Administrative Court will review the BAMF's decision.
If it agrees with the BAMF, the case will be dismissed.
The obligation to leave the country remains in force.
If the administrative court does not agree with the BAMF, you will receive a residence permit.
The BAMF is then obliged to grant you protection.
You can also take legal action against a positive decision by the BAMF.
For example, if you do not agree with the form of protection granted (exception: recognition of refugee status).
You should always seek advice and representation from a specialist lawyer for asylum and residence law.

question: What does confidentiality mean in an internship?
context:
Rights and obligations during an internship
Internship contract
No internship contract is required.
But it's good to have an internship contract.
This is because the regulations for the internship are laid down there.
Working hours
Depending on age, there are different regulations on working hours during internships:
Under 15 years of age: Work is generally prohibited.
This does not apply to internships for school pupils, for example.
Adolescents aged 13 and over may also carry out light activities (e.g.
e.g. tutoring, delivering newspapers).
Young people under the age of 15 are under special protection: they may work a maximum of 7 hours per day and a maximum of 35 hours per week.
Between the ages of 15 and 18: Young people of this age may work a maximum of 8 hours per day and a maximum of 40 hours per week.
Over 18 years: The regular working time of 8 hours per day should apply.
However, regular means that there may be exceptions.
If there is a lot to do, interns are allowed to work more than 8 hours.
A maximum of 10 hours may be worked per day.
Breaks
People on internships may and must also take breaks.
Age also plays a role in the break times:
Under 18 years of age: If you work between 4.5 and 6 hours, you must take a 30-minute break.
For more than 6 hours even 60 minutes.
Over 18 years: If you work for more than 6 hours, you must take a 30-minute break.
For working hours of more than 9 hours, even 45 minutes.
Duty of confidentiality
Interns learn a lot about the company during their internship.
Much of the information is confidential.
This means that interns are not allowed to pass on this information.
This is called "confidentiality".
For example:
One person is doing an internship in a doctor's surgery.
She learns a lot about the patients there.
For example, the names and illnesses of the patients.
She must not disclose this information to anyone.
Illness
In the event of illness, the intern must inform the internship company immediately.
Interns often need a medical certificate from a doctor.
It is best to ask the internship company whether a certificate is required.
Vacation
There is no entitlement to vacation during a mandatory internship.
It is possible to take vacation during a voluntary internship.
But only if the internship lasts more than 4 weeks.
The vacation days depend on the age of the intern and the duration of the internship.
Behavior in the workplace
Interns mean time and work for the internship company.
Interns should be aware of this.
Interns should therefore behave accordingly.
You can find tips on this under "Ten tips for interns".
Entitlement to an internship certificate
Interns are entitled to an internship certificate.
This means that the company or business must issue an internship certificate.
The internship certificate is important for the intern.
It helps later when applying for an apprenticeship or job.
It describes which activities the intern has carried out.
Sometimes the assessment of your performance during the internship is also included in the certificate.

question: How long do asylum seekers have to live in an initial reception center?
context:
Registration
Have you just arrived in Germany?
And you want to apply for asylum?
Then you must register with one of the government agencies immediately after your arrival:
Border authority
Police
Immigration office
Reception center for refugees
Branch office of the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF)
Your personal data is registered and stored centrally.
It is checked whether
You are applying for asylum in Germany for the first time
you have already applied for asylum in another European country
the Federal Criminal Police Office has data about you
You will then receive proof of arrival as proof of registration.
Only at this point does the asylum procedure begin.
Asylum application in the district of Augsburg
Would you like to apply for asylum in the Augsburg district?
Then contact the responsible authority:
Government of Swabia
Central Foreigners Authority Swabia
Kobelweg 82
zab-poststelle@reg-schw.bayern.de
You will then be sent to another initial reception center.
Or you can initially stay in the initial reception center in the district of Augsburg.
The law obliges asylum seekers to live in an initial reception center for a period of up to three months.
The reception center where you will be accommodated depends on your country of origin.
Asylum applications from different countries of origin are processed in the various BAMF branch offices.
All asylum seekers are distributed evenly among the various federal states in Germany.

question: Where can I find the AVV timetables with the fare zones?
context:
Public transportation
There is a good network of public transportation in Augsburg and the surrounding area, such as buses and streetcars.
The Augsburger Verkehrs- und Tarifverbund (AVV) is responsible for this network.
You can find all the important information on the AVV website at www.avv-augsburg.de.
For app users, both AVV (app: AVV.mobil) and Stadtwerke Augsburg (app: swa FahrInfo) offer free apps for download.
You need a ticket to travel by bus or streetcar.
Checks are often carried out on buses and streetcars.
If you do not have a ticket, you will have to pay a fine.
The second time, you will be reported to the police and fined much more.
So make sure you always have a valid ticket with you!
Fare zones and price levels
The area in which the AVV operates is divided into zones.
The price of the tickets depends on the number of zones traveled through.
The more zones you pass through, the more expensive your ticket will be.
Each zone corresponds to a price level.
Each zone is only counted once.
For example, if you travel through zones 20, 10 and 20 again, you need a ticket for price level 2 or
2 stripes on the stripe card.
However, the outward and return journeys count as two separate journeys.
The Augsburg city area includes fare zones 10 and 20.
The district of Augsburg comprises zones 30 - 70.
You can find the fare zone map here.
The timetables with the fare zones are also displayed at the stops.
Note: Your ticket is also valid if you change trains.
The most important tickets
Detailed information on all tickets and current prices can be found here.
Germany ticket
For 49 euros a month, you can use all means of public transportation and travel throughout Germany.
The Deutschlandticket is a subscription.
This means that it is automatically renewed every month.
But you can cancel it every month.
Always by 10.
of each month (for example: 10.
March) for the following month.
You can order your Germany ticket here.
It is then played on the smartphone.
You will need the "myAVV" app for this.
You can find the app in your smartphone's Apple or Google store.
Discount ticket for students, trainees, civil servants or volunteers
In Bavaria, these groups of people can get a discounted Deutschlandticket.
The discount ticket costs 29 euros.
It is also valid nationwide.
This ticket is valid for trainees from 01.
The person's place of education or residence must be in Bavaria.
To apply, you need a certificate of eligibility from your training center / educational institution.
You can apply for the discount ticket here.
Stripe card
9 strips for flexible use (one strip per zone)
Valid for 3 hours (no return and round trips)
No take-away options (one strip per person and zone)
You can find more information about the strip card here
One-way tickets
Once from A to B
Valid for 1 hour (no return and round trips)
No take-away options
4 Stops after boarding buses or streetcars, even across zone boundaries
Change possible
You can find more information about one-way tickets here.
Day ticket
Any number of journeys on the selected day
For adults aged 15 and over
For one person or groups (each additional person costs an extra charge)
Up to 4 children under the age of 14 can travel free of charge.
Valid Monday to Friday from 9:00 a.m., Saturday, Sundays and public holidays all day;
valid until closing time (i.e. until the last bus or streetcar leaves).
Please note: The names of the passengers must be handwritten on the day ticket!
You can find more information about the day ticket here.
365-euro AVV ticket for school pupils, trainees, interns and FSJ volunteers
The 365-euro AVV ticket is available for school pupils, trainees, interns and young people doing a voluntary social year.
For €1 a day, you can travel as often as you like on streetcars, buses and trains throughout the AVV network area - around the clock!
You can pay for the ticket in installments or all at once.
You can find all the information here.
Monthly pass for school pupils
Pupils do not have to pay for the bus and streetcar themselves.
You can submit an application.
The cost of the monthly pass will then be covered.
For this, the journey to school for pupils in grades 1 to 4 must be more than 2 km.
For children and young people from the 5th grade onwards, the journey to school must be longer than 3 km.
Further information and download of the applications: www.landkreis-augsburg.de
Call and collect cab (AST), on-call bus
The call-and-collect cab (AST for short) and the on-call bus operate when there are no regular bus or train connections.
For example, a cab will pick you up from the station or a bus stop and take you to the door of your desired destination.
The journey request must be made by telephone at least 30 minutes before departure.
The regular AVV prices apply.
You can find more information here.
AktiVVO - minibus as required
The minibus runs on demand without fixed stops and without a fixed timetable.
Trips in the minibus can be booked by telephone or in the "AktiVVO" app.
Within a short time, passengers can get on and off at one of the AktiVVo stops or at the AVV regional bus stops.
The fare for the AktiVVo corresponds to the regular AVV fares.
The AktiVVO minibus commutes in these regions:
Holzwinkel and Altenmünster, Roth and Zusam valleys
Bobingen, Königsbrunn and Schwabmünchen
The AktiVVO is only on the road in these regions.
He's not going to Augsburg either.
It does not travel to any locations outside these regions.
Augsburg City Zone
In the city of Augsburg, you can use the bus and streetcar free of charge at a total of 9 stations around Königsplatz and the main railway station.
The free stops are one stop in each direction from Königsplatz and Moritzplatz.
You can find more information here.
At night
With the night bus you are also mobile at night (0.30 to 4 am).
The night buses run from Thursday to Sunday and on public holidays.
Passengers require a special night ticket (also available on the buses).
Regional trains run on some routes.
The regular AVV fare applies here.

the central location between Munich and Stuttgart
its proximity to the city of Augsburg
ideal transport connections.

question: What happens when the time changes from winter to summer time?
context:
Public holidays, school vacations and time changeover
Holidays
No work is done on a public holiday for religious or secular reasons.
Stores and authorities are closed on these days.
The following holidays are on the same date every year:
01.01.
New Year
06.01.
Three Wise Men
01.05.
Labor Day
08.08.
Peace Festival (only in the city of Augsburg)
15.08.
Assumption of the Virgin Mary
03.10.
Day of German Unity
01.11.
All Saints' Day
25.12.
1st Christmas Day
26.12.
2nd Christmas Day
Other holidays shift from year to year.
You can find an overview of public holidays in Bavaria here.
School vacations
Vacations are the times of the year when pupils are off school.
In Bavaria, the new school year begins every year in September.
Fall vacation: There is a week around All Saints' Day (public holiday).
Christmas vacation: There are two weeks around Christmas and New Year (public holidays).
Winter vacation: There is a week's winter vacation in February.
Easter vacation: There are two weeks of vacation in spring
Whitsun vacation: There are two weeks of vacation in early summer.
Summer vacation: In summer, the school year ends at the end of July/beginning of August with six weeks of vacation.
You can find an overview of all upcoming public vacations and vacations here, for example.
Religious holidays
Jewish, Muslim and Orthodox pupils are exempt from lessons on certain religious holidays: www.km.bayern.de/ministerium/termine/ferientermine.html
Please inform the school if your child cannot come to school due to these holidays.
Intercultural calendar
The intercultural calendar provides an overview of the most important holidays of the different religious communities.
Time change
There is also a time change in Germany.
This means that the clock is set forward by one hour from winter to summer time.
The clock is set back by one hour from summer to winter time.

context:

Holidays
No work is done on a public holiday for religious or secular reasons.
Stores and authorities are closed on these days.
The following holidays are on the same date every year:
01.01.
New Year

Three Wise Men

Day of German Unity

All Saints' Day
25.12.
1st Christmas Day
26.12.
2nd Christmas Day
Other holidays shift from year to year.
You can find an overview of public holidays in Bavaria here.
School vacations
Vacations are the times of the year when pupils are off school.
In Bavaria, the new school year begins every year in September.
Fall vacation: There is a week around All Saints' Day (public holiday).
Christmas vacation: There are two weeks around Christmas and New Year (public holidays).
Winter vacation: There is a week's winter vacation in February.
Easter vacation: There are two weeks of vacation in spring
Whitsun vacation: There are two weeks of vacation in early summer.
Summer vacation: In summer, the school year ends at the end of July/beginning of August with six weeks of vacation.
You can find an overview of all upcoming public vacations and vacations here, for example.

Jewish, Muslim and Orthodox pupils are exempt from lessons on certain religious holidays: www.km.bayern.de/ministerium/termine/ferientermine.html
Please inform the school if your child cannot come to school due to these holidays.

question: What documents are required to enter Germany?
context:
Entry - Visa procedure
Entry as part of a visa procedure
If you are entering Germany with a D visa for a longer stay, you must note the following after your arrival:
First you have to register at your chosen place of residence.
German law stipulates a period of 14 days for this.
In the district of Augsburg, you register at the residents' registration office in your town hall.
Here you will find a list of all municipalities and town halls in the district.
After successful registration you will receive a registration certificate.
The second step is to apply for a residence permit:
The national visa (category D) will be issued to you for entry.
It is not issued for the planned duration of your stay.
That is why you need a residence permit.
You must apply for a residence permit at the Foreigners' Registration Office.
It is important that you apply for a residence permit while your visa is still valid.
The residence permit is limited in time and can be extended.
The residence permit also depends on the reason for your entry,
whether you are allowed to work or not,
what work you are allowed to accept and
whether time restrictions apply to employment in Germany.
Extension of the residence permit:
Please note that you should apply to extend your residence permit 6 to 8 weeks before it expires.
Depending on the purpose of your stay, there may be other things to consider.
You can also obtain this information from the Foreigners' Registration Office.

The Bavarian school system enables every child to follow an individual educational path.
Various qualifications can be obtained at all schools.
With every school-leaving qualification achieved, the path to the next higher qualification is open.

question: What are house rules?
context:
House rules, waste separation and energy saving
House rules
The cohabitation of many or more people in one house requires mutual consideration and tolerance.
The landlord can stipulate certain rules for the cohabitation of tenants in an apartment building.
These rules are then laid down in the house rules.
The most important contents of house rules are
Quiet times/noise
Waste disposal
Use of the common areas
Ventilate
You can find detailed house rules in different languages here: www.allbau.de/kundenservice/hausordnung
Waste separation
Waste must be disposed of in the garbage cans provided.
There are different garbage cans for plastic, paper and cardboard, for fruit and vegetable waste (organic waste) and for other waste.
Please keep to waste separation, as a large part of the waste is reused and it is an important part of environmental protection.
What belongs in which garbage can?
When are the garbage cans emptied?
Where is there a recycling collection point?
You can find information at www.awb-landkreis-augsburg.de.
You can also use the AbfallApp.
If you have any further questions, you can contact the waste advisory service of the district of Augsburg.
Waste consulting
abfallwirtschaft@LRA-a.bayern.de
You can find information on waste separation here.
Saving energy through ventilation and correct heating
Make sure that you ventilate regularly.
This means that you open the window fully for five minutes at least three times a day.
It is also important that you heat correctly.
This will prevent mold from forming and you can save energy.
You can obtain detailed information and helpful tips in German, English, Russian, Arabic and Farsi from the consumer advice center: www.verbraucherzentrale.de (search term: "multilingual information").

question: How can you report dangerous spots on cycle paths?
context:
In nature
In the Nature Park - Western Forests
The Western Forests Nature Park is the only nature park in Central Swabia.
It is a valuable recreational area for people from the city and district of Augsburg.
You can enjoy nature on hikes and bike tours.
The adventure trails provide lots of information about native plants.
You can find more details at www.naturpark-augsburg.de.
Lakes in the district of Augsburg - recreation and swimming fun
Whether in winter or summer: the lakes in the Augsburg region guarantee a welcome change from everyday life.
From a simple walk to a relaxing sunbath to sports activities such as diving or beach volleyball - there's something for everyone here!
Our lakes: Badesee Kühlenthal, Ilsesee Königsbrunn, Badesee Gablingen, Rothsee Zusmarshausen
Cycle paths in the district of Augsburg - Explore the district by bike
Enjoying nature, exploring the countryside and exercising in the fresh air?
What better way to do this than by bike!
The district of Augsburg therefore has a well-developed network of cycle paths.
Whether you are a family outing, an everyday cyclist or a top athlete - there is a suitable cycle route for everyone here.
So get on your bike and discover the district!
More information at: www.landkreis-augsburg.de/radwege.
For people who enjoy cycling, the Augsburg district cycling officer is open to requests, ideas and criticism.
Cycling officer
Jonas Fricke
radverkehr@LRA-a.bayern.de
Have you discovered a disturbing or dangerous spot on the cycle path?
With the RADar reporting platform, you can easily report annoying or dangerous spots.
Help the district of Augsburg to make the cycle paths safer.
At www.landkreis-augsburg.de/radar or via the free "RADar!" app.
Leisure tips in the great outdoors
Bonstetten land art trail - art meets nature
For art lovers, the land art trail designed by Hama Lohrmann with nine stations around Bonstetten offers a special approach to the theme of transience.
The starting point is the first station in the town center.
The signposted path then leads over an approx.
six-kilometer circuit through the adjacent western forests.
Land Art Trail Bonstetten
www.kunstpfad-bonstetten.de/
Perennial meditation path - time for peace and contemplation
Beautiful scenery, peace and quiet, time for yourself - that's what the meditation trail in the Augsburg - Western Forests Nature Park offers.
Nine stations with meditation exercises from various religions promise relaxation.
The route extends via Fischach, Langenneufnach, Walkertshofen, Mittelneufnach to the district of Unterallgäu.
On foot or by bike: relaxation is guaranteed!
Bonstetten Geological Trail - The history of the Staufenberg
Do you know why there are so many lakes in the foothills of the Alps?
No?
Then visit the geological nature trail in Bonstetten!
The nature trail is located on the Staufenberg and is 4.5 kilometers long.
The history of the landscape's formation during the cold and warm periods is vividly described with the help of six information boards.
The circular route begins in the center of Bonstetten: www.bonstetten.de/index.php/geologischer-lehrpfad

question: Where can I find religious communities?
context:
Religion
Religion in Germany
Germany is a predominantly Christian country.
Many people belong to the Catholic or Protestant faith.
Of course, there are also many people who belong to other faiths.
In the meantime, many people no longer have a denomination.
This means that you do not belong to any religious community or denomination.
Christianity continues to play a major role in Germany.
That is why there are also many statutory Christian holidays.
Other religious holidays are also observed at school.
Pupils who wish to celebrate religious holidays may be exempted from school.
This should be discussed with the school at an early stage.
Faith is a private matter in Germany.
State and religion are separate.
However, the state and religion work closely together.
For example, there are religious education classes at school.
In Germany, every person is free to choose their own faith.
Religious freedom is a valuable asset.
Religious freedom
Religious freedom is the law in Germany.
Every person has the right to choose and practice their own faith.
The Basic Law must not be violated in the process.
Religious freedom includes:
All people are free to practise and choose their religion and beliefs.
All people have the freedom not to be religious.
Anyone who does not believe in God is allowed to say so publicly.
People of different religions and beliefs are allowed to marry each other.
A marriage must be performed at the registry office.
Only then is it a legally valid marriage.
Any person may also marry within the framework of religion.
However, this is not legally binding in Germany.
The Basic Law can be read in nine languages (German, Arabic, English, Farsi, French, Kurdish-Kurmanci, Russian, Spanish, Turkish): www.bamf.de (search term: "Broschüre: Das Grundgesetz").
Religious houses and associations
There are various intercultural associations, religious sites, initiatives and organizations in the district of Augsburg and the city of Augsburg.
You can find a list here.

question: Where can I find a driving school for the German driving license?
context:
Car and moped
German driver's license
You need a driver's license to drive in Germany.
You have to get your driver's license at a driving school.
You have driving lessons there.
At the end you have an exam.
The exam consists of two parts: A written part and a practical part.
You have to pay for the driver's license yourself.
You may drive a car alone from the age of 18.
Young people can get their driver's license at the age of 17.
However, they may only drive with an adult.
This is called "accompanied driving".
Foreign driver's license
Would you like to drive in Germany?
And you already have a driver's license from your home country?
Then your driver's license may also be valid in Germany.
However, you may also have to retake the practical and/or theoretical exam.
The driver's license of people with EU citizenship is generally recognized.
Driving licenses from third countries such as Syria, Iraq or Afghanistan are usually not recognized in Germany.
The theoretical exam is available in many languages: German, Arabic, Turkish, Spanish, French, Russian, Polish, Romanian, Italian, Portuguese and English.
The driving license authority can answer questions about your driving license:
Driving license authority
fahrerlaubnis@LRA-a.bayern.de
Opening hours and further information can be found at www.landkreis-augsburg.de/auto-verkehr.
Moped driver's license
You also need a driver's license for a moped.
You have to take driving lessons at a driving school.
You then have to pass an exam.
You have to pay for the driver's license yourself.

question: Who can offer support if you disagree with the rejection?
context:
Decision of the BAMF
Decision on the asylum application
After the personal interview, the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees checks all descriptions, information and evidence.
It is checked whether one of the four forms of protection exists on the basis of the Asylum Act:
Eligibility for asylum
Refugee protection
subsidiary protection
Ban on deportation
The asylum application will only be rejected if none of these forms of protection can be recognized.
The decision will be justified in writing and sent as a "notification" to
the applicant, or
to persons who have been authorized in these proceedings (lawyers).
the responsible foreigners authority.
The decision is negative
If your asylum application is rejected, you will receive a negative decision and a deportation warning.
Deportation threat means: You will be asked to leave the Federal Republic of Germany by a certain date.
If you do not leave the country by this date, you may be forcibly deported.
There are two different types of rejection:
simple refusal: you must leave the country within 30 days.
Rejection as "manifestly unfounded": In this case, the deadline for leaving the country is only one week.
Contestation
If you do not agree with the rejection, you can take legal action against the decision in both cases.
This must be done very quickly after receiving the decision.
Therefore, go immediately to the integration and refugee counseling service in your accommodation.
You will receive support there.
You should always seek advice and representation from a specialist lawyer for asylum and residence law if you wish to take legal action.
You will be informed of all deadlines and legal options in the written notification: This information is referred to as "information on legal remedies".
Voluntary departure
If you decide to leave voluntarily, you can receive financial support for a new start in your country of origin.
You can get advice on voluntary departure here:
Central Return Counseling South Bavaria
info@zrb-suedbayern.de
www.zrb-suedbayern.de/
Inform the immigration office as soon as possible that you wish to leave the country voluntarily.
The decision is positive
You are recognized as entitled to protection.
The next steps are:
Fictitious certificate or
Electronic residence permit (eAT): Immediately after the positive BAMF decision has been delivered, you must apply for an identity document or residence permit.
take care of an equivalent.
You can obtain this from the Office for Immigration and Integration.
You are now allowed to work in Germany without restrictions.
If you don't have a job and are dependent on support, you will no longer receive the money from the social welfare office.
You must submit an application to the Jobcenter.

question: Are there German language courses for beginners near me?
context:
Offers for children
German with a sock
German with Socke is a movie series.
It enables children between the ages of 5 and 10 to take their first steps in the German language.
In the individual short videos, Esther (a young woman) talks to Socke (a red sock) about all sorts of things - just like in real life.
Sock is red, imaginative, a bit cheeky and full of energy.
This leads to many situations in which Esther and Socke speak and act together in German.
Children can easily identify with Socke.
This is also the aim of this material: the children - like Socke - should be able to have their say and act in the foreign language.
There are activities and a student booklet to go with the videos.
The bee rescuers
With this free app, children aged 3 and over can learn German through play.
With no prior knowledge of the language, they leave the shelter of the forest together with the squirrel and bear.
They embark on an exciting journey to save the sick bees.
On their way through the snow-covered mountains, they meet animals that help them.
And who teach them more than 900 German vocabulary words.
"The Bee Saviors" can be played on two different difficulty levels and offers up to six hours of fun.
Vocabulary app for children
With the "phase6 hallo Deutsch" app, school-age children (and teenagers) learn German in a fun way.
Each word is first introduced and then practiced with various exercises.
Illustrations and educational games help with this.
The show with the elephant
The little blue elephant and his friends present stories to discover, marvel at and laugh along with for children aged 3 to 6.
One shipment takes approx.
25 minutes and is also very suitable for language development.
Children's channel WDR Mouse
The page with the mouse offers children between the ages of 6 and 9
Knowledge programs (in which, for example, the manufacture or function of an everyday object is explained)
Audio stories
Games
Craft tips
A "Sendung mit der Maus" program presents complex issues in an entertaining and understandable way for children.
One episode lasts approx.
30 minutes.
It is also suitable for language development for children with previous knowledge.
Lingo for kids
With Lingo, children aged 8 to 12 can practise German and learn new things.
There are exciting texts to read and listen to, experiments and craft tips.

question: What type of training is school-based training?
context:
School education
How does school-based training work?
You learn a profession mainly in theory at school.
Depending on the profession, you will attend a vocational college, a technical college or a vocational college.
You do internships to gain practical experience.
The apprenticeship lasts two to three and a half years, depending on the profession.
You don't usually receive a salary during your training.
Some professions in Germany can only be learned in school-based training, for example dietician or healthcare and nursing assistant.
How do I find an apprenticeship?
If you would like to do a school-based apprenticeship, apply directly to the school.
In the district of Augsburg, you can complete school-based training at five vocational schools (BFS for short):
BFS for nutrition and care, BFS for childcare and BFS for dietary assistance at the vocational school center / Neusäß
BFS for Nursing / Bobingen
BFS for emergency paramedics / Schwabmünchen (private)

question: Where can I search for an apprenticeship online?
context:
Dual education
Germany is well known for its dual training system.
There are approx.
325 recognized training occupations.
How does dual training work?
You will learn the theory at vocational school one or two days a week.
You will learn practical work in a company three to four days a week.
The apprenticeship lasts two to three and a half years, depending on the profession.
You receive a salary.
How much you earn varies depending on the industry, company and year of training.
There are around 330 professions that can be learned in dual training.
Information films from the Federal Institute for Vocational Education and Training show exactly how dual training works in ten languages.
Arabic, Chinese, German, English, Farsi, French, Italian, Portuguese, Russian, Spanish
How do I find an apprenticeship?
If you would like to complete a dual apprenticeship, you must first find a training place.
You are applying for an apprenticeship at a company (company, firm, institution).
"Training place" means: You have a job in a company.
There you will learn the practical work for the profession.
Only then is it time to register for vocational school.
The company is responsible for registration.
The following online job boards will help you to find an apprenticeship:
Job exchange of the employment agency: www.jobboerse.arbeitsagentur.de
IHK apprenticeship exchange: www.ihk-lehrstellenboerse.de
HWK apprenticeship exchange: www.hwk-schaben.de/lehrstellenbörse
Azubiyo apprenticeship exchange: www.azubiyo.de/ausbildung
Training market: www.ausbildungsmarkt.de
AUBI-Plus: www.aubi-plus.de
Apprenticeship radar: www.lehrstellen-radar.de
In addition to these apprenticeship exchanges, there are many others on the Internet.
You can also use these.
You will also find apprenticeships
through the "AzubiWelt" app from the Federal Employment Agency (www.arbeitsagentur.de/azubiwelt)
in newspapers,
on company websites,
through unsolicited applications.
Which vocational school should I go to?
The vocational schools usually have a specialization.
In the district of Augsburg, for example, there are two departments at the Neusäß State Vocational School Center: Business and administration (office, industry, retail, wholesale) and agriculture (agriculture, horticulture, floristry).

question: How long does dual training take and what advantages does it offer?
context:

Germany is well known for its dual training system.
There are approx.
325 recognized training occupations.
How does dual training work?
You will learn the theory at vocational school one or two days a week.
You will learn practical work in a company three to four days a week.
The apprenticeship lasts two to three and a half years, depending on the profession.
You receive a salary.
How much you earn varies depending on the industry, company and year of training.
There are around 330 professions that can be learned in dual training.
