question: Which age group is particularly affected by meningococcal disease?
context:
Further STIKO vaccination recommendations
1. tBE (tick-borne encephalitis)
TBE is transmitted via tick bites.
Possible consequences of the disease are inflammation of the brain, the meninges and the spinal cord.
Bavaria, Baden-Württemberg and southern parts of Hesse, Thuringia and Saxony in particular are considered risk areas in Germany.
Vaccination against TBE is recommended by the STIKO in these areas in particular.
All children can be vaccinated against TBE from their 1st birthday.
2. flu (influenza)
Influenza is as contagious as a normal cold (flu-like infection).
Transmission in kindergartens and schools usually occurs from child to child.
Or about objects.
Children with pre-existing conditions are particularly affected.
They can lead to complications such as pneumonia.
The recommendation for an annual flu vaccination is therefore only aimed at children with a higher risk of complications.
You can find further information on the pre-existing conditions concerned here.
3. HPV (human papillomavirus)
Papillomaviruses can cause cancer in the long term.
Vaccination can therefore reduce the risk of cancer of the cervix, anus, penis and throat.
Vaccination before the first sexual contact offers the best protection.
Both vaccinations are recommended between the ages of 9 and 14.
4. meningococci
Meningococci are bacteria that can cause bacterial meningitis or blood poisoning (sepsis).
Children under the age of 5 and adolescents in particular are among the risk groups.
Vaccination against meningococcal type C is recommended at the age of 12 months.
There is currently no general recommendation for vaccinations against other types (B and ACWY).
The bacteria are transmitted via the so-called
Droplet infection.
This means, for example, coughing, sneezing or kissing.
5. pneumococci
Pneumococcus is the most common pathogen causing serious bacterial infections.
They can cause meningitis, pneumonia or middle ear infections.
They are particularly dangerous for babies and small children.
Three vaccinations against pneumococci are recommended.
These should be administered at the same time as the vaccination against tetanus, diphtheria and whooping cough.
6. rotaviruses
Rotaviruses are the most common cause of diarrhea and vomiting in children.
The pathogen is very contagious.
This is why almost all children contract the disease in the first five years - usually at the age of 2.
In infants in particular, a large loss of fluids and salt can lead to dangerous dehydration.
This may have to be
be treated in hospital.
Vaccination against rotaviruses is given two or three times, depending on the vaccine.
The first vaccination should be given between 6 weeks and 2 months of age.
The second vaccination at 3 months.
And the third, if necessary, at 4 months.
Vaccination against the coronavirus is currently only recommended for children aged 5 to 11 years with the "Comirnaty" vaccine from BioNTech/Pfizer.
Vaccinations can be given three to six weeks apart between the first and second vaccination.
The vaccination recommendation is primarily aimed at children who have an increased risk of a severe course due to a previous illness.
In addition, the recommendation also applies to children who are surrounded by people with a high risk of severe COVID-19 if they cannot be vaccinated themselves or the vaccination protection is not sufficient.
There is currently no recommendation for children without pre-existing illnesses or pre-existing illnesses of close contacts.
Nevertheless, it is possible to have your child vaccinated after consulting a doctor.
Further information on the pre-existing conditions concerned can be found at:
https://www.zusammengegencorona.de/impfen/kinder/corona-schutzimpfung-ab-5-jahren/
Further information on the vaccination recommendations mentioned here.

question: What are the two different cell phone contracts in Germany?
context:
Smartphone
There are two different cell phone contracts in Germany: Prepaid contract and fixed-term contract.
The prepaid contract has no fixed contract term.
This means that you pay a certain amount for a certain period of time (often four weeks).
You do not have to cancel the prepaid contract if you no longer want to use it.
A fixed-term contract has a minimum contract term.
This means that you have to stay with a particular provider for a longer period of time.
The contract is automatically extended if you do not cancel.
If you do not want the contract to be extended automatically, you must cancel in writing.
Pay attention to the notice period.
Ten important questions for concluding a contract:
How high is the basic fee?
Does the fee increase after a certain time?
Is there a minimum monthly turnover (minimum costs per month)?
How long does the contract last (e.g.
B.twelve or 24 months)?
If I don't cancel the contract, it will be automatically renewed.
When do I have to cancel if I don't want to extend the contract?
How much does it cost to set up, switch and deactivate?
Which time cycle (60/1, 10/10) is used for the calculation?
How much does a minute cost (external/own network)?
How much does a cell phone with a contract cost and how much does a cell phone without a contract cost?
How much does the Internet cost?
How much do international calls cost?
You can find important information in five different languages (German, English, Arabic, Russian, Farsi) at the consumer advice center: www.verbraucherzentrale.de (search term: "multilingual information").
There you will also find explanatory videos on the topic in German, English, Arabic and Dari.

question: What happens if Germany is not responsible for carrying out the asylum procedure?
context:
Dublin procedure
Dublin procedure
The Dublin procedure covers the 28 EU member states as well as Norway, Iceland, Liechtenstein and Switzerland.
The Dublin procedure determines which country is responsible for carrying out your asylum procedure.
As a rule, it is the country in which you were registered for the first time.
This is done with an electronic data comparison.
It may be that Germany is not responsible for carrying out your asylum procedure.
If Germany is not responsible, you will be sent back to the country responsible for you.
If you do not agree with this decision, you can seek advice.
You can get professional legal advice on whether it makes sense to file a complaint with the administrative court.

question: What is the difference between a home birth and a hospital birth?
context:
Important information about pregnancy
First appointment with the gynecologist
Pregnant women in Germany enjoy special protection and are entitled to advice, medical care and support with new purchases for the child.
If you are pregnant, you must first go to your gynecologist.
Have the preventive check-ups carried out there.
You will then receive a maternity pass.
The maternity record is a document containing important information about your pregnancy, your health and that of your child.
Always take your maternity pass with you in case of emergencies.
Maternity protection for working pregnant women
Working pregnant women have special protection - known as maternity protection.
Maternity protection begins 6 weeks before the birth and ends 8 weeks after.
This protection is regulated by law in Germany.
Pregnant women are generally not allowed to work during this time.
Your job is retained and you can return to work at the end of your maternity leave.
In addition, pregnant women may not work more than 8.5 hours per day and may not perform heavy physical labor.
Midwife
Midwives support women and their families from the beginning of pregnancy to the end of breastfeeding.
Midwives provide advice during pregnancy, can help with the birth, introduce breastfeeding after the birth and also take care of the woman's physical and psychological recovery.
Every woman can call on the help of a midwife.
Most services are covered by health insurance.
Website Midwives Association in German and English
You can find a midwife in the Rems-Murr district here
Pregnancy counseling
Women and men can go there for free and anonymous advice on all questions, issues and changes relating to pregnancy and family planning.
Regardless of whether they need medical or legal information, for example.
The counseling service is also available for mothers and young families after the birth of a child.
Women and men with an unfulfilled desire to have children can also seek advice.

schwanger@rems-murr-kreis.de
pro familia Waiblingen
waiblingen@profamilia.de

If you have little or no income, you can apply for unemployment benefit II or assistance under the Asylum Seekers' Benefits Act (AsylbLG).
After the twelfth week of pregnancy, the Jobcenter or social welfare office will pay expectant mothers additional needs and initial equipment for pregnancy and baby.
Child benefit
As a rule, all children in Germany are entitled to a child allowance from birth until they reach the age of 18.
You are entitled to child benefit from the age of 18.
In individual cases, the entitlement may last longer.
Parental allowance
Many parents want to look after their child after the birth.
In return, they do not work for a certain period of time.
Or they only work part-time.
Parental allowance is paid during this time.

question: Where can I find support for my job search?
context:
Entry from Ukraine and stay in Germany
Current information and entry requirements:
Federal Foreign Office
Federal Office for Migration and Refugees.
Further information specifically for the Rems-Murr district can be found here.
Can I enter Germany legally and stay there legally?
Foreigners normally require a residence permit - such as a visa or a residence permit - to enter and legally reside in Germany.
Due to the special situation in Ukraine, an exception has been made: War refugees from Ukraine are temporarily exempt from the requirement of a residence permit in Germany.
As things stand at present, this exception applies to first-time entries up to 31.
What happens after entry?
Where can I register in Germany and where can I get accommodation and meals?
The procedure is divided into four consecutive steps:
First registration
Distribution to a place of residence (if receiving social benefits)
Registration of the residential address at the destination
Application for a residence permit.
Further information can be found here.
Can I work in Germany with a residence permit for temporary protection?
Yes, that is possible.
However, gainful employment must first be permitted by the foreigners authority.
The immigration authority will already enter in the residence permit that gainful employment is permitted when issuing the residence permit.
This means that no further work permit from another authority is required.
Should Ukrainian nationals apply for asylum?
No, that is not necessary.
The necessary protection is granted in a different, faster procedure.
Ukrainian nationals are therefore advised to refrain from applying for asylum.
However, the right to submit an application for asylum at a later date continues to exist regardless of this.
Information portal of the German government
The Federal Ministry offers a digital information service in German, English, Russian and Ukrainian.
Here you will find all the official information about residence and living in Germany.

question: What is the difference between discounters and supermarkets?
context:
Shopping facilities
In Germany, stores are generally open from Monday to Saturday.
They are generally closed on Sundays and public holidays.
The opening hours of the stores may vary.
You can find out more on the Internet or at the entrance to the respective stores.
Restaurants, cafés and leisure facilities (e.g. swimming pools, museums, cinemas) are also open on Sundays and public holidays.
You can shop here:
Discounter
You can buy cheaper food in the discount stores.
The range of goods is relatively limited and simply presented.
There are discount stores in almost every town.
Supermarkets
In the supermarkets you can mainly buy slightly more expensive food.
You will also find many branded products here.
Greater emphasis is placed on the presentation of the goods than at the discounters.
Weekly markets
At the weekly markets you can buy mainly regional foods (e.g. fruit, vegetables, eggs, bread).
The weekly markets only take place on certain days of the week and usually in the mornings.
However, not every town has a weekly market.
Specialty stores
Specialty stores are stores where you can buy goods in a particular category.
These are, for example, bakeries, butchers, sports stores and shoe stores.
Retail stores with foreign products
Especially in larger cities, there are stores where you can buy foreign products.
For example, there are Turkish, Russian and Asian grocery stores.
Drugstores
Drugstores are specialist stores with an extensive range of products.
You can mainly buy hygiene products (e.g. shampoo, cleaning products) or cleaning products (e.g. washing powder, washing-up liquid) here.

Notice periods
Both sides - employee and employer - must adhere to these agreements.
As the contract becomes legally binding when you sign it, you must only sign it once you have fully understood its contents.

A lawyer, for example, can help you with this.

An employment contract can also be established verbally or tacitly through conclusive behavior!
If you have worked, your employer must pay you for it, even if you do not (yet) have a written employment contract!

Permanent employment contract
There is usually a probationary period of three or six months.
During this period, an employment relationship can be terminated by either the employer or the employee at short notice within two weeks.
At the end of the probationary period, a permanent employment relationship begins with longer protection against dismissal.
Working hours are usually up to 40 hours per week.
Fixed-term employment contract
The employment relationship ends on the agreed date without the need for notice of termination.

Regulated professions
You may only work in regulated professions if you have a certain qualification.

Medical professions

For all children in Germany, there is a right of residence from birth until they reach the age of 18.
Entitlement to child benefit from the age of 18.

Year of life.

question: How can I apply for housing benefit?
context:
I have found an apartment
Rental agreement
The amount of rent is agreed in the rental contract.
If the tenant signs this, he also agrees to pay the rent.
The rent is made up of basic rent (basic amount), ancillary costs (refuse collection, operating costs) and heating costs.
The rental agreement specifies when the rent is to be paid.
If the rent is increasingly not paid on time, this can lead to termination of the tenancy agreement.
You must read the rental agreement carefully.
If you don't understand everything, ask someone who can help you.
The rental agreement is very important.
Once it has been signed, it cannot be terminated so quickly!
The following points must be included in the rental agreement:
Name and address of the landlord
Address of the rental property
Living space in m²
Number of rooms
Amount of the net cold rent
Amount of operating costs
Amount of heating costs
Total rent
Amount of the deposit
If you agree with what is written in the rental agreement, then sign it.
Further information in several languages is available here.
Security deposit
The deposit is a security for the landlord/landlady.
The maximum amount for the deposit is 3 basic rents.
If you move out of the apartment and leave no damage behind, you will get your money back.
Possible assumption of costs
If you receive money from the Jobcenter or the district office, you must observe the following:
Important: You may not sign the rental agreement yet, but must first have it approved.
First of all, you must obtain a cost estimate from your future landlord.
This should include:
The amount of the rent
The amount of ancillary costs (heating, water, electricity)
The amount of the deposit
Possible graduated rent (automatic rent increase)
You must go to the job center / district office with the cost estimate.
They check the cost estimate.
If everything is in order, they approve it.
If you have a residence permit, you must submit an application to the immigration authorities.
Initial equipment
If you receive benefits from the Jobcenter, you have the option of applying for initial equipment for furniture and furnishings.
You will be paid a lump sum.
It is important that the application is submitted before the furniture is purchased
Caution: It may take some time before the money is paid out!
The Jobcenter also has the right to inspect the apartment in order to check the amount of initial equipment.
Information for refugees: When moving out of accommodation, you are not allowed to take the accommodation's furniture with you.
That's why you need new furniture.
You can submit an application for initial equipment to the Jobcenter.
Housing benefit
If you and the people living in your household earn little money, you are entitled to housing benefit under certain conditions.
If you receive money from the state for yourself and your family, you do not usually need to apply for housing benefit.

question: How can I apply for a work permit with tolerated stay?
context:
Can I work with a tolerated stay permit?
Permission to work with a tolerated stay permit depends on this,
whether you are living in an initial reception center or have already been accommodated outside the initial reception center
how many months you have already been in Germany.
They are still living in the initial reception center
If you are in possession of a tolerated stay permit for 0-6 months, you are not allowed to work.
If you have a tolerated stay permit according to §60a for at least 6 months, you are only allowed to work with the permission of the immigration authority.
You will find this information on your identity document as an additional provision.
You may be granted an employment permit.
You must complete and sign the job description and the declaration of employment and submit it to the Foreigners' Registration Office.
The approval of the Federal Employment Agency is requested by the Foreigners' Registration Office.
It checks the working conditions (e.g. minimum wage, scope of work).
You no longer live in the initial reception center
If you are in Germany for 0-3 months, you are not allowed to work.
If you have already been in Germany for 4 months, you can apply for an employment permit at the Foreigners' Registration Office.
Your identity document states "Gainful employment only permitted with the approval of the foreigners authority."
This means that you must fill in and sign the job description and declaration of employment and hand it in to the Foreigners' Registration Office.
The approval of the Federal Employment Agency is requested by the Foreigners' Registration Office.
It checks the working conditions (e.g. minimum wage, scope of work).
The granting of an employment permit is at the discretion of the immigration authority.
If you have already been in Germany for 4 years, a general work permit applies.
They have full access to the labor market.
This means that approval from the Federal Employment Agency is no longer necessary.
You do not generally need a work permit for school-based training.
Persons with a tolerated stay permit according to §60a AufenthG
There is a ban on working if:
They entered Germany with the motive of obtaining asylum seeker benefits.
The deportation is not possible for a reason for which the applicant is responsible and which is the cause of the impossibility of deportation.
Persons with a tolerated stay permit §60b AufenthG
Tolerance for persons "with an unresolved identity"
Gainful employment is not permitted for these persons (work ban).
This toleration is granted to persons who have not fulfilled their obligations to cooperate.
Obtaining a passport and clarifying identity
It is very important that you cooperate in obtaining a passport and clarifying your identity.
Otherwise, the immigration authority or the regional council may issue you with a general work ban under immigration law.
If you have such a work ban, you cannot submit an application to the Foreigners' Registration Office for admission to employment/training or continuation of existing employment.
If you have any further questions, please contact your social services department or the responsible integration management team.

question: What is the broadcasting fee and who has to pay it?

What are broadcasting fees?
Germany has independent radio, television and online offerings from ARD, ZDF and Deutschlandradio.
They report free from economic and political influences.
Everyone pays money for this together.
This is called the broadcasting fee.
The law stipulates that a broadcasting fee must be paid for every home in Germany.
However, only one person per home has to pay the license fee.
Further information can be found here in various languages.
Do I also have to pay?
Some people can be exempted from payment.
For example, if you receive benefits under the Asylum Seekers' Benefits Act or other social benefits.

question: What rights are laid down in the Basic Law?
context:
Basic Law and human rights
The Basic Law
In every country there are rules that everyone has to abide by.
The most important law for Germany is the Basic Law.
It is a collection of 146 articles.
Each article stands for a law, i.e. a rule.
These rules determine how we live together in Germany.
Fundamental rights protect the freedom of each individual.
They are laid down in Articles 1 to 19 of the Basic Law (catalog of fundamental rights).
Here you will find the Basic Law in various languages.
Universal Declaration of Human Rights
Human rights are important rights that always apply to all people around the world.
Human rights are rights that every person has by virtue of being human.
They protect the dignity of every human being and are equally due to all human beings without distinction of any kind, such as skin color, gender, language, religion, political or other opinion, national or social origin, wealth, birth or other status.
There are 30 rights.
The most important are:
All people are worth the same.
Everyone is allowed to have their own opinion.
Right to peace and security.
The rules for living together in Germany are derived from these fundamental rights.
The State Office for Political Education of North Rhine-Westphalia has published the brochure "Demokratie für mich" (Democracy for me), in which these rules are clearly presented.
These rules and examples of what is and is not permitted in Germany are presented here under each keyword.

question: How many people live in the Rems-Murr district?
context:
Interesting facts about the Rems-Murr district
Facts, figures and data
The Rems-Murr district is located in the Stuttgart region of Baden-Württemberg.
The district takes its name from the Rems and Murr rivers.
With an area of 858 km² and 426,635 inhabitants, the Rems-Murr district is one of the larger districts.
A total of 31 towns and municipalities belong to the Rems-Murr district.
These include the six large district towns of Backnang, Fellbach, Schorndorf, Waiblingen, Weinstadt and Winnenden.
Economy
The Rems-Murr district is an attractive business location for large companies as well as small and medium-sized enterprises.
A special feature is its commercial and industrial structure.
There are numerous large companies in the Rems-Murr district, such as Stihl (chainsaws), Bosch (household appliances) and Kärcher (household appliances).
Around 15 percent of employees work in the mechanical engineering sector.
This is a state record in Baden-Württemberg.

question: What is gender equality in Germany?
context:
Equal rights for men and women
Women and men have the same rights.
Women and men have the same duties.
This is reflected in the laws and in daily life.
This means, for example:
Girls and boys go to school together and receive the same lessons.
They take part in sports lessons together.
Women are allowed to study or learn a trade.
In principle, all professions are open to women.
Women take on responsibility in society, for example as policewomen, doctors, teachers or in public offices and authorities.
Their instructions must be followed.
Women decide for themselves what kind of work they want to do.
They can dispose of the money they earn themselves.
Women do not have to ask their husband, parents or other family members for permission to work, open an account or conclude contracts.
Women are allowed to dress as they wish.
Women decide for themselves whether, when and whom they want to marry.
Mothers are particularly protected.
You must and may not work for six weeks before and eight weeks after the birth.
They may not be dismissed because of their maternity.
The tasks and roles in the family are not prescribed.
Women participate in public life.
They attend cultural, political or sporting events, restaurants and bars.
Women can vote and be elected to political office.
Women and men are equal in inheritance law, daughters as well as sons.
Sexual touching, comments or requests are only permitted if everyone involved agrees.
A "stop" or "no" must always be respected.
This is not permitted in Germany, for example:
Any form of violence against women, including in marriage.
No one may be sexually harassed.
Rape, even within marriage, is punished.
No one may be forced to marry.
Coercion into marriage by force or threat is punishable.

If your child is ill or cannot go to school for other important reasons, you must report it to the school.
Please call the school before the start of lessons.

This is a letter from the parents.
The written excuse must often be received by the school within three days.
If your child is ill for a longer period of time, they will need a doctor's note.
The certificate must also be handed in at school.
It is best to ask the secretary what the school needs.
If your child does not come to school without a telephone or written excuse or a medical certificate, the school must look for your child.
If necessary, the school will even search for your child with the police.

question: What religious freedom is there in Germany?
context:
Religious freedom
Religion and faith are private matters in Germany.
The state does not dictate to anyone whether and in which God he or she should believe.
State and religion are separate.
This means, for example:
All people are free to practise and choose their religion and beliefs.
All people have the freedom to be non-religious and to say so.
Anyone who does not believe in God is allowed to say so publicly.
Members of different religions and faiths are allowed to marry each other.
Marriage only counts as a legally valid marriage if it is concluded before the registry office.
Marriages entered into exclusively within the framework of a religion are not legally binding in Germany.
This is not permitted in Germany, for example:
Putting religious rules or traditions above applicable laws, for example being married to several women at the same time or slaughtering an animal without special permission.
Boys may only be circumcised if this does not endanger their welfare.
Many people in Germany today are committed to dialog between religions.
The aim is the peaceful coexistence of religious people, people of faith and people of no religion.
The state is committed to ideological neutrality.
As long as the practice of a religion does not endanger democracy or the separation of state and religion, it is protected.

question: How can I find a kindergarten place?
context:
Where can my child be looked after before and after school?
Reliable elementary school
At the reliable elementary school, children are looked after directly before and after lessons.
Children can be looked after for up to six hours in the morning.
This also includes lessons and breaks.
Childcare can be provided from 7 a.m. to 1 p.m., for example.
However, the reliable elementary school ends at 2 p.m. at the latest.
The reliable elementary school takes place in the school or in rooms next to the school.
The children are usually looked after by teachers during this time.
There are often also various activities, for example sports or creative activities.
If your child is to attend the reliable elementary school, you must register him/her.
The reliable elementary school costs money.
Ask at the school or the town hall whether there is a reliable elementary school.
Ask there for further information (costs, registration).
Flexible afternoon care
Some schools offer flexible afternoon care.
These are offers in the afternoon.
These offers take place at the schools.
Flexible afternoon care begins at 12 noon at the earliest and ends at 5.30 pm at the latest.
If your child is to take part in afternoon care, you must register your child.
Flexible afternoon care costs money.
Ask at the school or at the town hall whether there is flexible afternoon care.
Ask there for further information (costs, registration).
Homework supervision
Many schools offer homework supervision after lessons.
During homework time, pupils are supervised and monitored.
The supervisor will help with any questions.
You may have to pay for homework supervision.
Ask the school whether homework supervision is available.
Hoarding
In after-school care, children are looked after by teachers.
It is also known as a day nursery.
Children can eat lunch, do their homework and play with other children in the after-school care center.
They can receive help with their homework from teachers.
The after-school care center is for elementary school children (1st grade).
grade to 4th grade).
Sometimes older children can also attend the after-school care center.
You have to register at an after-school care center.
After-school care costs money.
The costs can be covered in full or in part by the Youth Welfare Office if you are unable to pay them.
To do this, you must submit an application to the Youth Welfare Office.
Ask at the school or town hall whether there is an after-school care center in your community.
Vacation care
In some municipalities there is a vacation care program.
Your children will be looked after there during the school vacations.
In some municipalities, vacation care is also called urban recreation.
There are many different activities for the children (games, sports, creative activities) during vacation care.
If your child is to take part in vacation care, you must register it.
Vacation care costs money.
Important: Holiday care does not normally take place during the entire school vacation.
Ask at the town hall whether there is vacation childcare available.
Ask there for further information (costs, registration, period).

question: What types of permanent residence permits are there?
context:

Permanent residence
Niederlassungserlaubnis (settlement permit) according to Section 9 Aufenthaltsgesetz
With the Niederlassungserlaubnis (settlement permit), you can live and work in Germany without time or location limits.
Requirements (selected):
Legal residence in Germany for at least five years (earlier study and training times are calculated at 50 percent)
Valid residence permit that was not issued for a temporary purpose (study) or for humanitarian reasons
Proof of secure living costs and housing
Proof of sufficient retirement planning (at least 60 months obligatory contributions or voluntary contributions to state pension insurance in Germany)
Sufficient German language knowledge and knowledge about the legal & societal rules and living conditions in Germany– usually proved by:
Confirmation that you have taken part in an integration course
or
Study certificates and references about completed job training in Germany or other language certificates
Further documents may be required in individual cases.
You can find more information on these requirements here.
Permanent residence – EU
The permission for permanent residence – EU (Daueraufenthalt – EU) is a permanent residence permit and offers the same rights as the Niederlassungserlaubnis (settlement permit).
With the permission for permanent residence, you can live and work in Germany without time or location limits.
Furthermore, you can fundamentally also live, work or study in the countries of the European Union (with the exception of Ireland, Denmark, Great Britain), (special requirements apply for individual countries).
You can find more information on these requirements here.
Whether a Niederlassungserlaubnis (settlement permit) or an Erlaubnis zum Daueraufenthalt– EU (permission for permanent residence) is better for you depends on your individual circumstances.

question: What are the steps for a longer stay in Germany with a D visa?
context:

If you enter with a D visa for a longer stay in Germany, you must be aware of the following when you arrive:
The first thing you must do is register in your chosen town/city of residence.
German law gives you a period of 14 days after your arrival to do this.
In München you register in the Bürgerbüros (Residents’ Office).
In order to register or re-register, you can go personally to the Bürgerbüro (Residents’ Office) or have a person authorised by you bring the registration form, filled in and signed.
In both cases you need an appointment which you can arrange
online.
After you have successfully registered you will receive a registration certificate (Meldebescheinigung).
In the second step you apply for a residence permit:
The national visa (category D) was issued to you to enter Germany.
It is not issued for the planned duration of your stay however.
That’s why you need a residence permit.
You have to apply for the residence permit at the»» Ausländerbehörde (Immigration Office).
It’s important that you apply for the residence permit while your visa is still valid.
The residence permit is temporary but can be extended.
Independently of the reason for your entry to Germany, the residence permit also regulates:
If you are allowed to work or not,
What work you are allowed to do and
If time limits apply for employment in Germany.
Extending a residence permit:
Please note that you should apply to extend your residence permit already six to eight weeks before it expires.
Independently of the purpose of your stay, there may be other things to take into account.

question: What are the consequences of overstaying a visa in Germany?
context:

Residence with a visa
If you enter Germany with a visa with which a longer stay is not intended, you must leave Germany within the validity period of the visa – i.e. at the latest on the last day of validity.
A Schengen visa that has not been issued for three months can be extended in Germany for a maximum period of three months within a deadline of six months, if the requirements still exist.
You are not allowed to change the purpose of the visa.
The application must be justified, in particular
Force majeure,
Humanitarian, professional or serious personal reasons
can be taken into account.
If you leave later, without asking permission of the »» Ausländerbehörde (Immigration Office), your stay would be without permission and an infringement of the law.
The Ausländerbehörde (Immigration Office) then checks how your stay ended.
It would only be possible for you to re-enter the country if you were not subject to a re-entry ban.
Legal action could also be taken against you.

Children and adolescents are offered ten medical check-ups (known as Früherkennungsuntersuchungen /U1 to U9 and J1) over the course of their childhood and adolescence.
These examinations are meant to check whether the child is healthy and developing well.
Parents are given advice about topics such as vaccinations, nutrition or linguistic and motoric development.
The U1 (examination after birth) and U2 (between the 3rd and 10th day of life) examinations usually take place in the maternity hospital.

The medical check-ups U1 to U9, which take place from the first days of life to the child’s 6th birthday, are compulsory in Bavaria.

Summer holidays
The timing of the summer holidays is different depending on which federal state you live in.

The autumn holidays take place around the public holiday Allerheiligen (All Saints’ Day, 01 November) and usually last a week.

The two-week Christmas holidays include Christmas Eve (24.12.) and the “Epiphany” public holiday (06.01.).
Spring holidays
The week-long spring holidays start on Rosenmontag (Carnival Monday).

Easter weekend takes place in the middle of the Easter holidays, which are always two weeks long.

Public holidays are days on which you don’t go to work, and shops and public authorities are closed.

others shift slightly from year to year.

question: Who has to pay social security contributions for a mini-job?
context:
Employment contract
Employment contract
Anyone who starts a job gets an employment contract.
It regulates the most important conditions of an employment relationship such as working times, holiday entitlement, amount of salary and periods of notice.
Both sides – workers and employers – must abide by these agreements.
As the contract becomes legally valid with your signature, you should only sign it when you fully understand the content.
Types of contracts:
Permanent job contract (Unbefristeter Arbeitsvertrag)
As a general rule, there is a probationary period of three to six months.
During this time, a working relationship can be cancelled by both the employee and the employer with a short notice period of two weeks.
At the end of the probationary period, a permanent employment relationship begins with longer protection against dismissal.
Working hours are usually up to 40 hours a week.
Fixed-term employment contract (Befristeter Arbeitsvertrag)
The employment ends at the agreed time, without the need for notice of resignation.
Mini-job (small-scale employment)
The maximum monthly income is 520 EUR and is tax-free.
The employee does not have to pay contributions to the state health insurance scheme or unemployment insurance;
you can also apply to be exempt from paying contributions to pension insurance.
With a mini-job, you only get very minimal entitlement to an old-age pension later.
You need to organise health insurance yourself;
it’s a good idea to ask one of the state health insurance companies for advice.

question: Who is responsible for legal issues of a young refugee?
context:

My stay in Germany– what is the legal situation?
A person at your final place of residence will supervise you and help you in all legal issues.
This person is your legal guardian.
What does a legal guardian do?
If a refugee who is younger than 18 year of age comes to Germany on their own, they require an adult to legally represent them in place of their parents.

The legal guardian has various tasks.
He or she:
Regularly keeps in contact with you
Represents your interests towards the Jugendamt (Youth Welfare Office), the Ausländerbehörde (Immigration Office) and other institutions
Accompanies you during your asylum procedure
Applies for any help you may need

At your new location you will live with other young people in one house.

What does Schulpflicht (compulsory education) mean?
In Germany, schooling is mandatory up until the age of 18.
This means that you go to school until you have a school qualification or start a training course/apprenticeship.
What educational possibilities do I have in Germany?
The type of school you will go to depends on how old you are and how long you have already attended school.

context:

Equal rights for women and men
Women and men have the same rights in Germany.
This is set down in article 3 of the German Grundgesetz (basic law).
Women can learn German, go to a doctor, learn an occupation and find work.
They don’t need the permission of their husband or other family members.
Women can marry who they want and also get divorced or separate from their husbands if the relationship doesn’t work out or if their partner is violent.
They can live in a relationship with a man or a women or they can live alone.
If couples separate, the children can live with the mother, the father or sometimes part-time with both parents.
If the parents cannot agree where the children should live, the courts decide what is best for the children.
Despite having the same rights, it can happen that women are disadvantaged in their job, everyday life or in the family.
There are various advice centres for women.
There you can find out about your rights and you get help so that you can lead an independent and equal life.

question: Who can receive housing benefits from the Job Centre?
context:

Benefits from the Job Centre
Who for: Households that receive financial support from the Jobcentre.
Rent and heating
Costs are covered if they are reasonable (§22 SGB II).
In the case of the City of Munich, fixed
rent ceilings apply.
For households with seven or more persons, the rent ceiling includes 15 m² and 270 Euros per additional person.
The amounts for the rent ceiling refer to the gross cold rent.
A gross cold rent is made up as follows:
Net cold rent = basic rent without operating costs
plus
cold operating costs = for example, the costs for refuse collection, (cold) water, staircase lighting, street cleaning and property tax.
Heating and hot water costs are taken into account separately.
Your benefits officer will explain to you how to proceed in case of unreasonable rent costs.
The "" Office for Housing and Migration of the state capital will advise you on all questions concerning housing in Munich.
If you are threatened with homelessness, we will look for a solution with you at
Sozialbürgerhaus.
Moving
If you want to move, your case worker must check whether the move is necessary and the costs of the new flat are reasonable before signing the tenancy agreement.
The following evidence and documents are required for the check:
Written justification of the reason for the move (if necessary, appropriate evidence proving an important reason).
Unsigned tenancy agreement or an offer of a flat showing all costs related to renting the flat (for example basic rent, ancillary costs and heating costs, deposit).
An important reason exists, for example, if:
the move remedies a threatened or existing homelessness;
the move ends or avoids the need for assistance;
the move is necessary in order to take up or continue employment subject to social security contributions at a greater distance (commute to work, depending on working hours, more than 2-2.5 hours total travel time).
Attention: If you rent a flat without the Job Centre's consent, you may suffer financial disadvantages.

question: What are the consequences of illegal employment in Germany?
context:
Irregular and illegal employment
Irregular and illegal employment
A job that is paid but not registered with the Finanzamt (tax office) and health insurance company, and for which thus no taxes and social security payments are paid, is illegal and is referred to in Germany as "Schwarzarbeit” or “moonlighting” in English.
It can be punished with fines and prison!
If someone gets social benefits or unemployment benefits, but still works and keeps their job secret from the Sozialamt (Social Welfare Office), the Arbeitsagentur (Employment Agency) or the Jobcenter, this is also illegal employment: A person is thus wrongly receiving state benefits, even though they are in paid employment.
This is forbidden and against the law.
In German it is known as “Schwarzarbeit”.
You should always inform the office where you get benefits if you want to start a job;
you are allowed to earn money while still receiving social benefits (the benefits are then recalculated) but you must inform the case officers of every kind of earnings and income immediately.
Taking up work even though you are forbidden to work is also regarded as illegal employment.
Depending on your country of origin and reason for staying, illegal employment can lead to you being permanently forbidden to work!

question: Who can attend the German courses for initial language orientation?
context:
German courses for initial language orientation
German courses for initial language orientation
The German courses for initial language orientation (also: initial orientation courses) provide both elementary knowledge of German as well as information about life in Germany.
They are a practical first step for participants in a new social environment and help with their orientation in everyday life.
One course comprises 300 lesson units, each 45 minutes long and covers topics such as “health/medical care”, “work”, “nursery/school”, “housing”, “orientation on site/traffic/mobility”.
Spoken communication is the main focus: Participants should learn as quickly as possible how to find their way around in everyday life.
In the case of initial orientation courses, it is also a question of teaching values.
Initial orientation courses are primarily intended for asylum seekers with an unclear prospect of permanent residence in Germany.
Provided that there are free places on the course, recognised asylum seekers, legally tolerated foreigners and asylum seekers with good prospects of permanent residence may also participate.
If you are still school age (6 to 15 years) or obliged to attend vocational college (16 to 21), you don’t attend the initial orientation course, but your school or educational facility.
If you are given access to an »» integration coursewhile participating in an initial orientation course, it is possible to switch to this course.
The people on the courses have very different educational backgrounds.
Illiterate people can attend the courses as well as university graduates.
Initial orientation courses are free.
The course language is German– interpreters are not present on the course.
Contact an »» Immigration Advice Centre or your »» Asylum and Integration counselling service on-site in your hostel.
They will help you to find a suitable course.
Find out more
People who are not eligible for this offer can contact the »» Integrationsberatungszentrum IBZ Sprache und Beruf (integration advice centre IBZ language and careers).
It organises supplementary German language courses.

Bicycle
Cycling in the district of Augsburg is lots of fun!
A well-developed network of cycle paths with excellent signposting makes cycling not only a sporting hobby, but also a healthy and affordable alternative to buses, trains and cars.
For those of us who love to ride their bike, here are a few tips:
Always drive on the right-hand side of the road
Do not ride side by side, but behind each other.
If there is a cycle lane, you must ride on the cycle lane (always on the right-hand side of the road in the direction of travel).
Only children up to11 years of age are allowed to cycle on footpaths.
It is dangerous if you get your tyres caught in the tram tracks.

If your bicycle is not properly equipped, you will have to pay a fine if it is checked by the police:
Light front and rear
Reflector front and rear

question: How can I enroll in a German integration course?
context:
Integration courses for adults
What is an integration course?
The Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF) offers integration courses.
In an integration course, you will learn German and many things about Germany.
For example on topics such as...
Work and career
Training and further education
Childcare and education
shopping
Housing
Rights and duties in Germany
How can I do an integration course?
When do I have to attend the integration course?
Voluntary attendance: Authorisation certificate required
Would you like to attend the course voluntarily?
Then you needauthorisation from the BAMF, a so-called "certificate of eligibility".
With this authorisation certificate, you can register for an integration course at a language school.
Whether or not you receive a certificate of eligibility depends on your residence status.
You can get help with this from the "Learn German" counselling service.
The counselling service can also help you with the application for the eligibility certificate.
Obligation from the Office for Immigration and Integration
Some people are required to attend an integration course by the Office for Immigration and Integration.
This means that they must attend the integration course.
Important information at a glance
- The general integration course lasts several months and takes place full-time or part-time (e.g. for people in employment).
- It consists of a language course with 600 teaching units (short: UE = 45 minutes) and an orientation course on life in Germany with 100 UE.
- The aim is to reach language level B1 on completion of the course.
You will then receive a certificate.
- The certificate is important.
For example, if you are looking for work or want to do an apprenticeship.
The certificate can also be important if you want to stay in Germany permanently and need a permanent residence permit.
- There are also special integration courses for certain groups of people.
For example, for women (with childcare), working people or people who cannot read and write.
- Participants with a BAMF authorisation certificate pay 220 euros per module (=100 hours).
They can get 50% of this back if they successfully complete the course within two years.
- Participants without a BAMF authorisation certificate pay 440 euros per module (=100 hours).
- The course is free of charge for recipients of social benefits.
They will be exempted from the costs on application.
Necessary travel costs can also be reimbursed.
The language counselling centres offer individual advice on this.

here.

question: What is the purpose of recognizing foreign professional qualifications in Germany?
context:
Recognition of foreign professional qualifications
Certificates play an important role in Germany for school, university or work.
They are proof of what you have already learnt and achieved.
Certificates of school-leaving qualifications or professional qualifications are the decisive prerequisite for getting a job, a training place or a place at university.
If you have already obtained qualifications at school, in an apprenticeship or at university abroad, it often makes sense for the certificates to be recognised in Germany.
This means that it will be checked what you are qualified to do with your certificates in Germany.
It may be that you no longer have your certificates.
In this case, you can try to prove your work experience and professional skills by taking tests.
IQ recognition and qualification counselling
Have you gained a vocational qualification abroad?
Have you already gained work experience abroad?
Then the Recognition and Qualification Counselling Service is the right place for you.
The counselling centre will look at your documents.
It then compares your qualification with the German qualification.
For example, the duration or content is compared.
Relevant work experience is also taken into account.
At the end, you will receive an assessment of whether you can get your qualification recognised or not.
Sometimes there are too many differences between the foreign and German qualifications.
Because there are many factors to consider when recognising professional qualifications, it is best to seek advice:
Door to door - Recognition and qualification counselling

Recognising a foreign qualification costs money.
The costs vary depending on the profession.

live permanently in Germany,
have a low income and

question: How many days per week do you learn theory in a dual apprenticeship?
context:
Dual apprenticeship
How does a dual apprenticeship work?
Candidates learn the theory at a vocational school (1 to 2 days per week) and the practical part at a company (3 to 4 days per week).
The training lasts two to three and a half years, depending on the profession.
Candidates receive a salary (just how much a person earns depends on the industry, company and year of the apprenticeship).
There are roughly 330 professions for which a candidate can undertake a dual apprenticeship.
Just how a dual apprenticeship works is explained in information films provided by the Bundesinstitut für Berufsbildung (Federal Institute for Vocational Education and Training) in 10 languages (Arabic, Chinese, German, English, Farsi, French, Italian, Portuguese, Russian, Spanish).
How do I find an apprenticeship place?
If you want to complete a dual training programme, you first have to find a training place.
You are applying for a training place at a company (enterprise, firm, institution).
"training place" means: You have a job in a company,in whichyou learn the practical work for the profession.
Only then comes the registration for the vocational school.
The company takes care of the registration.

question: Who should get vaccinated against meningococcal type C?
context:
Further vaccination recommendations of the STIKO
1. TBE (early summer meningoencephalitis)
TBE is transmitted via tick bites.
Possible consequences of a disease are inflammations of the brain, the meninges and the spinal cord.
Especially Bavaria, Baden-Württemberg and southern parts of Hesse, Thuringia and Saxony are considered risk areas in Germany.
Especially in these areas, vaccination against TBE is recommended by the STIKO.
All children can attend from the age of 1. The vaccination against TBE must be carried out before the child's 60th birthday.
2. Influenza (flu)
Influenza is contagious in a similar way to a normal cold (flu).
Transmission in kindergartens and schools usually occurs from child to child or via objects.
Children with pre-existing conditions are particularly affected.
Complications such as pneumonia can occur in them.
The recommendation for annual flu vaccination is therefore only aimed at children with a higher risk of complications.
You can find more information about the affected pre-existing conditionshere.
3. HPV (human papilloma viruses)
Papilloma viruses can cause cancer in the long term.
Vaccination can therefore reduce the risk of cancers of the cervix, anus, penis and throat.
Vaccination before the first sexual contact offers the best protection.
Both vaccinations are recommended between the ages of 9 and 14.
4. Meningococcus
Meningococci are bacteria that can cause bacterial meningitis or blood poisoning (sepsis).
Children under the age of 5 and adolescents are particularly at risk.
Vaccination against meningococcal type C is recommended at the age of 12 months.
There is currently no general recommendation for vaccination against other types (B and ACWY).
The bacteria are transmitted via so-called droplet infection, i.e. for example via coughing, sneezing or kissing.
5. Pneumococcus
Pneumococcus is the most common pathogen of severe bacterial infections.
They can cause meningitis, pneumonia or middle ear infections and are especially dangerous for babies and small children.
Three vaccinations are recommended against pneumococci, which should be administered at the same time as the vaccination against tetanus, diphtheria, whooping cough.
6. Rotaviruses
Rotaviruses are the most common cause of diarrhoea and vomiting in children.
The pathogen is very contagious, which is why almost all children contract it in the first five years - usually at the age of 2. Especially in infants, a large loss of fluids and salt can lead to dangerous dehydration, which may have to be treated in hospital.
Rotaviruses are vaccinated two or three times, depending on the vaccine.
The first vaccination should be given between 6 weeks and 2 months of age, the second at 3 months and the third, if necessary, at 4 months.
Vaccination against the Corona virus is currently recommended for children aged 5 to 11 years only with the vaccine "Comirnaty" from BioNTech/Pfizer.
Vaccinations can be given at intervals of three to six weeks between the first and second vaccination.
The vaccination recommendation is primarily aimed at children who have an increased risk of a severe course due to a previous illness.
In addition, the recommendation also applies to children in whose environment there are persons with a high risk of a severe COVID-19 course, if they themselves cannot be vaccinated or the vaccination protection is not sufficient.
There is currently no recommendation for children without their own pre-existing conditions or pre-existing conditions of close contacts.
Nevertheless, it is possible to have your child vaccinated after consulting a doctor.
For more information on the affected pre-existing conditions, see:
https://www.zusammengegencorona.de/impfen/kinder/corona-schutzimpfung-ab-5-jahren/
Further information on the above vaccination recommendations here.

question: How many weeks before the expiration date should one apply to extend their residence permit?
context:

Entry as part of a visa procedure
If you are travelling to Germany on a D visa for a longer stay, you must note the following after your arrival:
Firstly, you must register at your chosen place of residence.
German law stipulates a period of 14 days for this.
In the district of Augsburg, you register at the residents' registration office in your town hall.
Here you will
find a list of all municipalities and town halls in the district.
Once you have registered, you will receive a registration certificate.
The second step is to apply for a residence permit:
The national visa (category D) will be issued to you for entry.
It is not issued for the planned duration of your stay.
You therefore need a residence permit.
You must apply for the residence permit at the immigration office.
It is important that you apply for the residence title while your visa is still valid.
The residence permit is limited in time and can be extended.
Depending on the reason for your entry, the residence permit also regulates
whether you are allowed to work or not,
what work you are allowed to accept and
whether time restrictions apply to employment in Germany.
Extension of the residence permit:
Please note that you should apply to extend your residence permit 6 to 8 weeks before it expires.
Depending on the purpose of your stay, there may be other things to consider.
You can also obtain this information from the Immigration Office.

question: Who is considered a refugee according to the Geneva Refugee Convention?
context:
Forms of protection in the asylum procedure
Forms of protection in the asylum procedure
Many people are persecuted in their home country.
People can receive protection in Germany.
To do so, you must apply for asylum.
By applying for asylum, you start an asylum procedure.
It decides whether you are allowed to stay in Germany.
There are different forms of protection under German law.
This is because there are different forms of persecution.
In the asylum procedure, your situation is analysed in detail.
You will then be granted a form of protection.
You can find an overview of the forms of protection here.
Under the links you will find information in German, English, Turkish, Russian, French and Arabic.
Entitlement to asylum
Politically persecuted people are granted asylum in Germany.
This is stated in the Basic Law (Art.
16 A).
You receive protection status if you are persecuted by the state in your home country because of
Your ethnicity
Your nationality
Your political convictions
your religion or
your membership of a particular social group (e.g. because of your sexual orientation).
Some people also fear punishment if they return to their home country.
This form of protection also applies in this case.
Find out more
Refugee protection
The Geneva Refugee Convention has defined who is considered a refugee.
The definition says: A refugee is outside the country of origin.
He or she is persecuted by a state or non-state because of one of the following characteristics
ethnicity
religion
nationality
political conviction
membership of a particular social group (e.g. due to sexual orientation)
Legal basis: Section 3 para.
of the Asylum Act (AsylG)
Learn more
Subsidiary protection
Subsidiary protection applies to people who are at risk of serious harm in their country of origin.
Or who cannot claim protection in their country of origin.
The threat can come from a governmental or non-governmental source.
These include
Death penalty
torture
inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment
serious individual threat to the life or integrity of a civilian due to indiscriminate violence in an international or internal armed conflict
Legal basis: Section 4 (1) AsylG
Learn more
National ban on deportation
A person seeking protection may not be deported if
the return would constitute a violation of the European Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (ECHR) or
there is a considerable concrete danger to life, limb or freedom in the country of destination.
Legal basis: Section 60 (5) AufenthG, Section 60 (7) AufenthG
Learn more

question: How can a newcomer register to vote?
context:
Right to vote
People in Germany have the right to vote.
They are allowed to vote for politicians.
That is written in a law.
And these are the most important elections in Germany:
Landtag election
You elect politicians for the Landtag in your federal state.
The Landtag decides things for the federal state.
A new Landtag is always elected after 5 years.
Election to the Bundestag
You elect politicians for the Bundestag.
The Bundestag decides things for the whole of Germany.
A new Bundestag is always elected after 4 years.
European election
You elect politicians for the European Parliament.
The European Parliament decides things for all countries in the European Union.
A new European Parliament is always elected after 5 years.
In Germany there are 2 different electoral rights:
1. the active right to vote
You have a German passport.
And you are 18 years or older.
Then you have the active right to vote.
This means that you can vote.
For example, in these elections:
Bundestag election
Landtag election
Local elections
Mayor election
Senior citizens' council election
2. the right to stand for election
You have a German passport.
And you are 18 years or older.
Then you have the right to stand for election.
This means: You can be elected by other people.
You can then work as a politician.
For example, you then work
For the German Bundestag
For the Landtag
For local government

With an area of 858 km² and a population of 426,635, the Rems-Murr-Kreis is one of the larger administrative districts.

The Rems-Murr district is an attractive business location for both large companies and small and medium-sized enterprises.

Dual training

Dual training takes place about one third of the time in vocational school and about two thirds in a training company.
In this way you get to know theory and practice at the same time and earn money in a company during your training.
If you want to apply for an apprenticeship, German language skills are very important (at least B1).

question: What is the purpose of a probationary period in a permanent job contract?
context:
Employment contract
Anyone who starts a job gets an employment contract.
The employment contract regulates the most important conditions of an employment relationship such as:
Working hours
Holiday
The amount of salary and
Periods of notice
Both sides - workers and employers - must abide by these agreements.
As the contract becomes legally valid with your signature, you should only sign it when you fully understand the content.
If you later discover that you have signed a contract with which you do not agree after all, you can have the clauses reviewed.
A lawyer can help you with this, for example.
You can get further support here.
Note:
An employment contract can also be established verbally or tacitly by conclusive conduct!
If you have worked, your employer has to pay you for it, even if there is no written employment contract (yet in place)!
Types of contracts
Permanent job contract (Unbefristeter Arbeitsvertrag)
There is usually a probationary period of three or six months.
During this period, both the employer and the employee may terminate an employment relationship at short notice within two weeks.
At the end of the probationary period, a permanent employment relationship begins with longer protection against dismissal.
Working hours are usually up to 40 hours a week.
Fixed-term employment contract (Befristeter Arbeitsvertrag)
The employment ends at the agreed time, without the need for notice of resignation.

question: Who can participate in the professional language course as an employee?
context:
Vocational Language Courses (DeuFöV)
Job-related German courses help to further improve one's German skills, for example after having already attended an integration course.
You can attend the so-called DeuFöV courses while you are working, undergoing training or a vocational qualification measure or as preparation for starting a career in Germany.
The basic structure of the professional language courses is the basic course.
A basic distinction is made between three types: B1 to B2, B2 to C1 and C1 to C2.
The modules each comprise 300 teaching units.
However, there are also special modules that only require speaking level A2 or B1.
Additional special modules are specifically adapted to specific occupational groups.
Who can participate?
You must meet the following requirements to participate in the professional language course:
They have a migration background and a need for further language training.
This is the case with immigrants from third countries, EU citizens and Germans with a migration background.
You have already completed an integration course and/or already speak German at A1, A2, B1, B2 or C1 level according to the Common European Framework of Reference (CEFR) for languages.
In order to attend courses with a target language level below B2, prior attendance of an integration course with a passed and failed German test for immigrants is required.
You must be registered as a job seeker and/or usually receive benefits according to SGB II ("Hartz IV") or SGB III (unemployment benefit).
You are looking for a training position or are already in training.
You are currently going through the recognition procedure for your vocational qualification or training certificate.
Participation as an employee
If you are already in employment, you can take part in the professional language course.
The prerequisite is that you do not yet have sufficient language skills to master your future everyday working life.
Cost of participation
Participation in the professional language course is generally free of charge.
If your taxable annual income is over €20,000, you pay a cost contribution of €2.42 per teaching unit (50 per cent of the cost reimbursement rate).
This is a total of 1,452 € for a course with 600 teaching units.
The payment of the cost contribution can also be made by the employer.
Upon successful completion of the examination, a refund of 50 per cent of the cost contribution can be applied for.
Eligibility
As a rule, the employment agencies and job centresdecide on eligibility.
Contact your counsellor here.
They will also know which language schools offer courses and whether special courses are possible for you.
If you are already working or in a training relationship or in the recognition procedure and do not receive benefits under SGB II or SGB III, you can apply directly to the BAMF for entitlement to participate.

question: What abilities does a person with level C1 have?
context:
What are the language levels?
The levels
The basic levels are:
A: Elementary language skills
B: Independent language skills
C: Competent language skills
These three levels are further subdivided into two levels each.
A detailed description of the knowledge behind each level can be found in the following table:
Level:
A1
Can understand and use familiar everyday expressions and very basic phrases.
This includes, for example, the question and answer regarding the place of residence.
A2
The person is able to understand sentences and frequently used expressions related to the essential aspects of everyday life.
This includes, for example, the description of your own job or training.
B1
The person understands the most important contents when using a clear standard language when dealing with familiar matters at work, school or leisure.
This enables the person to express themselves in a simple and coherent way about familiar topics and personal areas of interest, for example, about what goals the person is pursuing.
B2
The person is able to understand the most important contents of complex texts and also understands technical discussions in his/her own special field, for example, in vocational school.
The person is able to communicate so spontaneously and fluently that a conversation with native speakers is easily possible without much effort on either side.
C1
The person understands a wide range of demanding, longer texts and can also perceive implicit meanings that are not expressed openly.
In addition, the person is able to speak spontaneously and fluently - for example at work - and to express himself or herself on complex topics.
C2
The person can understand practically everything he or she reads and hears without effort.
They can express themselves spontaneously, very fluently and precisely.

question: Who receives a "Tax ID number" in Germany?
context:
Taxes and social security payments
Every employee in Germany pays a part of his or her wage as taxes and social security contributions.
Self-employed persons must also pay taxes.
Income tax
Income tax is a contribution to financing federal, state and local government spending.
With the money from taxes, streets and schools are built or social benefits are financed, for example.
If you have an employer (i.e. are “angestellt”), you will receive the net sum of your salary from your employer – in other words, your taxes have already been deducted.
If you are self-employed, you are responsible for your own income tax
Tax ID number
All working persons receive a “Tax ID number” when they start work.
The tax ID is a 11-digit number and is used for income tax.
It is valid for the whole of your life.
Children born in Germany receive a letter with their personal tax ID within three months after the birth;
this is required to apply for child benefit (Kindergeld) for example.
If you work in Germany, you will need the number again and again, for example, for your employer.
If you do not know the number, you can ask for it personally at the Meldebehörde (registration office) or in writing from the Bundesamt für Steuern (federal tax office).
Tax return
In the annual tax return, you can claim various expenses from the Tax Office to reduce the amount of tax you pay.
You can receive refunds or you may have to pay additional payments to the Tax Office.
Many people are obliged to complete a tax return;
it is best to ask the Finanzamt (tax office) if this applies to you.
If you need help with your tax return, you should contact your local taxpayer’s advice centre.
If you have further questions, the tax office can also help you.
Social security payments
Social security contributions are the contributions to social insurance that employees have to deduct from their gross monthly wage in addition to taxes - this is legally obligatory and is automatically calculated by the employer.
Part of social insurance is also paid by the employer.
The social security payments finance the German social insurance system.
If people can't find work, or are no longer able to work, their key living costs will still be covered.
Ultimately, social contributions serve the personal security of each and every individual - for example, if you become unemployed and have previously paid into unemployment insurance for a certain period of time, you are entitled to unemployment benefit I. Likewise, with your monthly contribution to pension insurance, you acquire a right to receive a state pension in old age.
The contributions to social insurance are made up of payments towards:
Pension insurance
Unemployment insurance
Health Insurance
Long-term care insurance
The amount depends on your individual income.
The contributions are automatically deducted from your gross salary.
There are exceptions for foreign workers, for example if they are sent by a foreign company to Germany, work in several countries or are self-employed or affected by other exemptions.
To receive a permanent residence, it’s a requirement that you have paid contributions for at least 60 months into pension insurance.
This also applies to self-employed people.
There are also exemptions here.
‘Sozialversicherungsnummer’ (social security number)
Deutsche Rentenversicherung (the German state pension insurance company) automatically sends you your social security number the first time you take up employment in Germany.
If you lose this number you can request to have it sent to you again:
Telephone number of the Deutsche Rentenversicherung:

question: Is attendance at a day care center mandatory for children in Germany?
context:
Day care centre/kindergarten
What is a day care centre?
Before your child goes to school, they can attend a day care centre.
There are carers there who look after your child and support their development.
They are like teachers at school.
Day care centre is a collective term for various forms of childcare.
It is often just called a "day care centre ". If your child is 1-3 years old, the daycare centre is called a "crèche".
The crèche is often integrated into a daycare centre.
If your child is 3-6 years old (until they start school), the daycare centre is called a " kindergarten".
The kindergarten is also called "Kiga" or "Kindi".
From the age of 1, your child has the right to attend a day-care centre or day-care facility.
Attending a day care centre/kindergarten/crèche is voluntary and costs money.
Here you can find a multilingual video about daycare centres.
Why is a day care centre good for my child?
At the daycare centre, your child can play with other children, make friends and learn lots of new things.
They will also learn the German language here.
At the day care centre, children learn while they play.
The day care centre is a very important preparation for school.
In the penultimate year and shortly before your child starts school, there is a school enrolment examination.
Here you can find videos about the day care centre in different languages.
How can I enrol my child in the daycare centre?
Ask at the town hall in your municipality how you can enrol your child.
The social counselling/integration manager in the shared accommodation or the migration counselling and youth migration service can also help you to register your child at the kindergarten.
Unfortunately, there are not enough places in all day care centres.
It is therefore best to enrol your child several months to a year in advance and have it placed on the waiting list.
When is the daycare centre open?
There are different opening hours.
In day care centres, you can normally have your child looked after from the morning until late in the afternoon.
However, there are also kindergartens that are only open until midday (approx.
12:00 or 14:00).
You bring your child to the daycare centre in the morning and pick it up again at lunchtime or in the evening.
This depends on how long you have booked.
There are fixed times for this.
You have to stick to them.
This is very important for the children.
This allows the carers to support the children undisturbed.
Find out more directly from the daycare centre.
Child day care centre

question: Where should you go to register a motor vehicle in Germany?
context:
Cars
Driving licence
If you drive a car in Germany, you must have a valid driving licence and always carry it with you.
In Germany, you can drive a car from the age of 18 and with a valid driving licence.
There is also the option of taking the driving licence at the age of 17.
You want to get your driving licence?
If you want to get your driving licence, choose a driving school.
The driving school will explain which documents you need and how to proceed.
Getting a driving licence costs money.
Please enquire in advance about the amount of these costs.
In order to get a German driving licence, you must pass the theoretical and the practical exam.
The theoretical examination can be taken in many languages other than German.
Talk to your driving instructor about this.
You must also attend a first aid course.
There you will learn how to provide help in an emergency situation, for example in case of accidents, burns and poisoning.
Here you can find more information and contact details on how to apply for a driving licence at the district office.
You already have a foreign driving licence?
You have a foreign driving licence and live in Germany?
In this case, your foreign driving licence is still valid for 6 months after you moved to Germany.
After these 6 months, you must transferyour driving licence to a German driving licence.
You will also have to take a theoretical and practical exam.
Persons from EU/EEA states with a valid driving licence do not need to transfer their foreign driving licence.
Here you can get further information as well as applications for the transfer of your driving licence.
Note: To ensure that road traffic is safe for you and others, there are many rules.
You must observe these when driving a car.
These rules are laid down in the Straßenverkehrs-Ordnung (StVO).
If you break these rules, you will be fined.
Penalties can be: Fines, a driving ban or points on your licence.
Here you will find further information in several languages.

question: What is the age limit for receiving child benefit?
context:
Child benefit and parental allowance
Child benefit
All children in Germany are entitled to child benefit from birth until they reach the age of 18.
In individual cases, this can also be up to the age of 25.
Your child must live in your household and be cared for by you.
Child benefit is only paid to one person at a time, usually one parent.
If you have several children, the individual amounts are paid out as one sum.
Often, you will receive at least € 250 per month for each child.
If you have several children, the number of children determines the amount of child benefit.
From the third child onwards, you are entitled to more child benefit.
How do I get child benefit?
You must submit an application to the Family Benefits Office (Familienkasse) of the Federal Employment Agency (Bundesagentur für Arbeit).
Please also contact your benefit provider (job centre or district office) for more information.
The application and further information on child benefit
Note for asylum seekers: You cannot receive child benefit during the asylum procedure.
This is only possible after you have received a positive decision from the BAMF.
Responsible for the Rems-Murr district: Familienkasse Baden-Württemberg-Ost (family benefits office).
Parental allowance
Many parents want to take care of their child after the birth.
To do so, you do not work for a certain period of time.
Or you only work part-time.
If you have applied for parental allowance, you can get at least 300 € every month.
But it can also be more.
You usually get parental allowance for 12 months.
But it can also be longer.
You get parental allowance if you have a residence and stay in Germany.
You need a residence permit.
You must live together with your child.

question: Which food assistance programs exist in Germany?
context:
What is the “Tafel” and who can visit there?
The Tafel helps people who don't have much money.
They offer cheap food and hygiene products that are no longer sold in the shops.
These include:
Foods with an imminent expiry date
Baked goods from the previous day
Damaged or dented packaging
Fruit and vegetables with small blemishes.
You can get food and toiletries from here if you do not work or do not earn enough money.
You willneed an ID card for this.
It is issued by the “Tafel” stores.
Go there with your proof that they are needy.
For example, with your official notice issued via the “AsylblG” or “Sozialhilfe” (these are the letters that state how much money you will receive for one month).
In the Rems-Murr district there are Tafel shops in the following towns:
Waiblingen, Fellbach, Backnang, Winnenden, Weinstadt, Welzheim, Murrhardt
Here you will find the respective addresses and contact details.

question: Where can one seek advice for health insurance in a minijob?
context:
Minijob
The maximum earnings per month are € 520 and are tax-free.
No contributions have to be paid by the employee to the statutory health insurance and unemployment insurance .
You can also be exempted from the obligation to pay pension insurance upon application.
With a mini-job, you acquire only very small entitlements to a later old-age pension.
You must arrange your own health insurance, so it is best to seek advice from a statutory health insurance company.

question: Who is responsible for social care in the shared accommodation?
context:
Social support in shared accommodation
Caritas and the Kreisdiakonieverband are responsible for social care in the shared accommodation facilities in the Rems-Murr district.
The main tasks are counselling, mediation and support in all matters of daily life, family, employment and the organisation of community life in accommodation and neighbourhood.
The tasks also include accompanying volunteers.
The contact details are posted in the respective accommodation.
For general questions regarding social care in the Rems-Murr district, you can also contact the following office:
Social management of refugee social care in the Rems-Murr district
sozialmanagement@rems-murr-kreis.de
